original_case_data.name: U.S. v. State of Connecticut
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On December 19, 2005 the Department of Justice (DOJ), Civil Rights Division, initiated an investigation into the conditions and practices at the Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), the largest of five state-run psychiatric hospitals in the State of Connecticut, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1997 (CRIPA).

A report of findings was submitted to the governor of Connecticut on August 6, 2007. The DOJ’s investigation found that CVH regularly failed to: (1) adequately protect patients from harm and undue restraints; (2) provide adequate psychiatric and psychological services; and (3) ensure adequate discharge planning and placement in the most integrated setting appropriate to each patient’s individualized needs. The report formally put CVH on notice that failure to improve conditions would result in a lawsuit.

On January 20, 2009, the Department of Justice filed suit against the state of Connecticut and its Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services in U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut for the aforementioned pattern of practices at CVH, that violated the constitutional and federal statutory rights of patients under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1997 (CRIPA). The lawsuit was filed along with a settlement agreement and joint motion to dismiss.  Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved the settlement on July 8, 2009 and conditionally dismissed the suit.

In the settlement, Connecticut agreed to a wide variety of practice changes and a period of supervised operation. The state agreed to provide care and treatment “based on professional standards of practice that shall seek to: A. ameliorate symptoms such that a less restrictive locus of treatment may safely be employed; B. strengthen and support individuals’ rehabilitation and recovery; and C. enable individuals and grow and develop in ways benefiting their health and well-being.”

The settlement called for an environment that maximizes safety and is predicated on respect between the staff and those whom they serve. In addition, it mandated implementation of integrated treatment plans and interdisciplinary staff teams to increase the efficacy of treatment provided. Furthermore, the settlement outlined extensive changes in the psychiatric and psychological care provided in order to increase the safety and wellbeing of patients while also reducing the risk of harm and suicide that was extensive at CVH. Across the board, the settlement emphasized that care provided be consistent with generally accepted professional standards of care and that the environment at CVH be sufficiently humane to reduce the risk of harm. The settlement outlined a 48-month period of supervised implementation after which the agreement would terminate provided that CVH had demonstrated substantial compliance with the terms.

On September 25, 2013, the Court approved a notice of substantial compliance with certain terms of the settlement agreement and extension of termination that was filed by the State. On May 22, 2015, the Court approved the State’s notice of substantial compliance and motion to terminate the settlement agreement, effectively terminating the Court’s ability to enforce the agreement.

Although the notice of substantial compliance and motion to terminate was accepted and granted, news suggests that as late as mid-2017, patients at the Connecticut Valley Hospital continued to suffer from widespread abuse. On September 6, 2017, the Connecticut State Police announced the arrests of nine CVH employees on charges on cruelty to persons and disorderly conduct. Reports from the Associated Press and Channel 3 Eyewitness News (the New Haven area CBS news affiliate) detail violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment suffered by inmates at the hands of CVH employees.
original_case_data.summary_short: On January 20, 2009, the Department of Justice filed and settled a lawsuit with the State of Connecticut for practices at the Connecticut Valley Hospital, a state-run psychiatric facility, that violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1997 (CRIPA). In the settlement, Connecticut agreed to a wide variety of practice changes and a period of supervised operation. On May 22, 2015, the Court approved the State’s notice of substantial compliance and motion to terminate the settlement agreement, however, news suggests that as late as mid-2017, patients at the Connecticut Valley Hospital continued to suffer from widespread abuse.

1.transformed_text:
The Department of Justice (DOJ), Civil Rights Division, initiated an investigation on December 19, 2005, into conditions and practices at the Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), the largest of five state-run psychiatric hospitals in Connecticut, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1997 (CRIPA).

On August 6, 2007, the DOJ submitted a report of findings to the governor of Connecticut, which concluded that CVH regularly failed to adequately protect patients from harm and undue restraints, provide adequate psychiatric and psychological services, and ensure adequate discharge planning and placement in the most integrated setting appropriate to each patient’s individualized needs. This report formally notified CVH that failure to improve conditions would result in a lawsuit.

On January 20, 2009, the DOJ filed suit against the State of Connecticut and its Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services in U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut, alleging that CVH's practices violated patients' constitutional and federal statutory rights under CRIPA. The complaint was filed concurrently with a settlement agreement and joint motion to dismiss, which Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved on July 8, 2009, leading to the conditional dismissal of the suit.

The settlement mandated a variety of practice changes and a period of supervised operation, requiring Connecticut to provide care and treatment based on professional standards of practice aimed at ameliorating symptoms for less restrictive treatment, strengthening rehabilitation and recovery, and promoting individuals' health and well-being. The settlement mandated an environment maximizing safety and respect, along with integrated treatment plans and interdisciplinary staff teams to enhance treatment efficacy. It further outlined extensive changes in psychiatric and psychological care to increase patient safety and well-being, reducing the significant risk of harm and suicide at CVH. Overall, the agreement emphasized care consistent with generally accepted professional standards and a humane environment to mitigate harm. A 48-month period of supervised implementation was stipulated, after which the agreement would terminate upon CVH demonstrating substantial compliance.

The State filed notices of substantial compliance, leading to the Court's approval on May 22, 2015, of the State’s motion to terminate the settlement agreement, thereby ending the Court’s enforcement authority.

Despite the Court's approval of the termination, reports as late as mid-2017 indicated continued widespread abuse of patients at CVH. On September 6, 2017, the Connecticut State Police announced the arrests of nine CVH employees on charges of cruelty to persons and disorderly conduct, with media reports detailing violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment suffered by patients at the hands of CVH staff.

1.transformed_text:
On December 19, 2005, the Department of Justice (DOJ), Civil Rights Division, started looking into the conditions and practices at the Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), the largest of five state-run psychiatric hospitals in Connecticut. This investigation was done under a law called the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA).

A report with their findings went to the governor of Connecticut on August 6, 2007. The DOJ's investigation found that CVH often failed to: (1) properly protect patients from harm and too much restraint; (2) offer enough psychiatric and psychological care; and (3) plan for patients to leave and live in the most independent setting right for them. The report officially warned CVH that if conditions didn't get better, a lawsuit would follow.

On January 20, 2009, the Department of Justice sued the state of Connecticut and its Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services in U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut. The lawsuit claimed that the practices at CVH violated patients' constitutional and federal rights under CRIPA. They filed the lawsuit along with a proposed settlement agreement and a joint request to dismiss the case. Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved the settlement on July 8, 2009, and dismissed the lawsuit, but with conditions.

In the settlement, Connecticut agreed to make many changes to its practices and operate under supervision for a time. The state agreed to provide care and treatment based on professional standards. This care would aim to: A. lessen symptoms so patients could be treated in less restrictive settings; B. help individuals with their rehabilitation and recovery; and C. allow individuals to grow and develop in ways that improve their health and well-being.

The settlement required an environment that was as safe as possible and built on respect between staff and patients. It also required using integrated treatment plans and teams of staff from different areas to make treatment more effective. Furthermore, it detailed major changes to psychiatric and psychological care. These changes aimed to boost patient safety and well-being, and lower the high risk of harm and suicide that was extensive at CVH. Overall, the settlement stressed that all care must meet generally accepted professional standards. It also said the environment at CVH needed to be humane enough to reduce the risk of harm. The settlement set out a 48-month period of supervised changes. After this time, the agreement would end if CVH showed it had largely followed the terms.

On September 25, 2013, the Court approved a notice from the State saying it had largely complied with some parts of the settlement, and extended the agreement's end date. On May 22, 2015, the Court approved the State's notice of substantial compliance and its request to end the settlement agreement. This meant the Court could no longer enforce the agreement.

Even though the notice of substantial compliance and the request to end the agreement were approved, news reports from mid-2017 suggest that patients at Connecticut Valley Hospital still faced widespread abuse. On September 6, 2017, the Connecticut State Police announced that nine CVH employees had been arrested for cruelty to persons and disorderly conduct. Reports from the Associated Press and Channel 3 Eyewitness News (the New Haven area CBS news affiliate) describe violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment that patients suffered from CVH employees.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine this: The U.S. government's Department of Justice (DOJ), specifically their Civil Rights team, began investigating what was happening at the Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH) on December 19, 2005. CVH is the biggest of Connecticut's five mental health hospitals run by the state. They did this under a law called the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), which is designed to protect people in places like hospitals and prisons.

They sent a report with what they found to Connecticut's governor on August 6, 2007. The DOJ's investigation showed that CVH often didn't do a good job of: (1) keeping patients safe from harm or from being held back too much; (2) giving them enough mental health care; and (3) helping them plan to leave the hospital and live as independently as possible. The report was a formal warning to CVH: if things didn't improve, the government would sue them.

On January 20, 2009, the Department of Justice took the state of Connecticut and its mental health department to court. The lawsuit said that what CVH was doing went against patients' basic rights under the Constitution and federal laws, specifically CRIPA. They filed the lawsuit, but also included a suggested agreement to settle the case, and asked the judge to close the lawsuit right away. Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved this agreement on July 8, 2009. He closed the lawsuit, but with certain conditions that the state had to meet.

In this agreement, Connecticut promised to make many changes to how it ran things and agreed to be watched for a period of time. The state agreed to give care and treatment that met professional standards. This care would aim to: A. reduce patients' symptoms so they could get help in less controlled environments; B. help people get better and recover; and C. allow them to grow and improve their overall health.

The agreement also said the hospital had to be as safe as possible and that staff and patients should treat each other with respect. It also required using complete treatment plans and having teams of staff from different areas work together to make care better. Plus, it laid out big changes for mental health care. These changes were meant to make patients safer and healthier, and to lower the high risk of harm and suicide that was common at CVH. Overall, the agreement emphasized that all care had to meet accepted professional standards and that the hospital environment needed to be kind and safe enough to reduce the risk of harm. The agreement set a 48-month (four-year) period for these changes to be watched closely. After this time, the agreement would end if CVH proved it had mostly followed the rules.

On September 25, 2013, the court agreed to a notice from the State saying it had mostly followed some parts of the agreement, and they extended the deadline for the agreement to end. Then, on May 22, 2015, the court approved the State's claim that it had largely met the requirements and its request to end the agreement. This meant the court could no longer make sure the agreement was being followed.

Even though the court said the State had mostly followed the rules and ended the agreement, news reports from mid-2017 showed that patients at Connecticut Valley Hospital were still suffering from a lot of abuse. On September 6, 2017, the Connecticut State Police announced that nine CVH employees were arrested. Their charges included cruelty to people and disorderly conduct. News stories from the Associated Press and a local TV station (Channel 3 Eyewitness News) described violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment that patients experienced from CVH employees.

4.transformed_text:
The U.S. government's Department of Justice started looking into a hospital. This was the Connecticut Valley Hospital, or CVH. It was December 19, 2005. CVH was the biggest state hospital for people with mental health issues in Connecticut. The government used a special law. It's called CRIPA. This law helps protect people in places like hospitals and prisons.

The government sent a report about what they found. They sent it to Connecticut's governor on August 6, 2007. The report said CVH often did not do a good job. They didn't keep patients safe from harm. They held patients back too much. They didn't give patients enough mental health care. They also didn't help patients plan to leave. Patients needed help to live on their own after the hospital. The report was a serious warning. It said if CVH didn't get better, the government would sue them.

On January 20, 2009, the Department of Justice sued Connecticut. They also sued the state's mental health department. The lawsuit said CVH was breaking patients' basic rights. These rights are protected by the Constitution and federal laws like CRIPA. The government filed the lawsuit. But they also offered a way to settle the problem. They asked the judge to close the case right away. Judge Alvin W. Thompson said yes to this plan. This was on July 8, 2009. He closed the lawsuit. But Connecticut had to follow certain rules.

In this agreement, Connecticut promised to change how the hospital worked. The state also agreed to be watched for a while. They said they would give care that was up to professional standards. This care would help patients in three ways. First, it would make their problems less severe. This way, they could get help in places that were not so strict. Second, it would help people get better and heal. Third, it would help them grow and feel healthier overall.

The agreement also said the hospital had to be very safe. Staff and patients should treat each other with respect. The hospital had to use full plans for how to treat each patient. Teams of different staff members had to work together. This was to make care better. The agreement also planned big changes for mental health care. These changes were to make patients safer and healthier. They also aimed to lower the high risk of harm and suicide at CVH. The agreement said all care must be professional and good. The hospital place itself needed to be kind and safe. This would help lower the risk of harm. The state had four years, or 48 months, to make these changes. They would be watched closely during this time. After four years, the agreement would end. But only if CVH showed it had followed most of the rules.

On September 25, 2013, the court agreed with Connecticut. The state said it had followed some parts of the agreement. So, the court gave them more time to finish. Then, on May 22, 2015, the court said okay again. Connecticut said it had mostly done what it promised. They asked the court to end the agreement. The court agreed. This meant the court could no longer check if the rules were being followed.

But even after the court ended the agreement, bad things were still happening. News reports from mid-2017 showed patients at CVH were still being hurt. They suffered a lot of abuse. On September 6, 2017, police announced arrests. Nine workers from CVH were arrested. They were charged with being cruel to people. They were also charged with causing trouble. News stories said workers were violent. They made patients feel ashamed. They also sexually harassed patients.

The lawsuit was filed along with a settlement agreement and joint motion to dismiss.  Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved the settlement on July 8, 2009 and conditionally dismissed the suit.

In the settlement, Connecticut agreed to a wide variety of practice changes and a period of supervised operation. The state agreed to provide care and treatment “based on professional standards of practice that shall seek to: A. ameliorate symptoms such that a less restrictive locus of treatment may safely be employed; B. strengthen and support individuals’ rehabilitation and recovery; and C. enable individuals and grow and develop in ways benefiting their health and well-being.”

The settlement called for an environment that maximizes safety and is predicated on respect between the staff and those whom they serve. In addition, it mandated implementation of integrated treatment plans and interdisciplinary staff teams to increase the efficacy of treatment provided. Furthermore, the settlement outlined extensive changes in the psychiatric and psychological care provided in order to increase the safety and wellbeing of patients while also reducing the risk of harm and suicide that was extensive at CVH. Across the board, the settlement emphasized that care provided be consistent with generally accepted professional standards of care and that the environment at CVH be sufficiently humane to reduce the risk of harm. The settlement outlined a 48-month period of supervised implementation after which the agreement would terminate provided that CVH had demonstrated substantial compliance with the terms.

On September 25, 2013, the Court approved a notice of substantial compliance with certain terms of the settlement agreement and extension of termination that was filed by the State. On May 22, 2015, the Court approved the State’s notice of substantial compliance and motion to terminate the settlement agreement, effectively terminating the Court’s ability to enforce the agreement.

Although the notice of substantial compliance and motion to terminate was accepted and granted, news suggests that as late as mid-2017, patients at the Connecticut Valley Hospital continued to suffer from widespread abuse. On September 6, 2017, the Connecticut State Police announced the arrests of nine CVH employees on charges on cruelty to persons and disorderly conduct. Reports from the Associated Press and Channel 3 Eyewitness News (the New Haven area CBS news affiliate) detail violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment suffered by inmates at the hands of CVH employees.

1.transformed_text:
As a Legal Historian, I observe that the story of Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH) began on December 19, 2005, when the Department of Justice (DOJ), Civil Rights Division, launched an investigation. This was a proactive step, taken under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), to determine if the state's largest psychiatric hospital was failing its patients.

The investigation's findings, delivered to Connecticut's governor on August 6, 2007, revealed deeply troubling conditions: patients were inadequately protected from harm and undue restraints, psychiatric and psychological services were deficient, and discharge planning was insufficient. This report served as a formal warning, a diplomatic attempt to prompt voluntary improvements and avert a lawsuit.

However, when these issues persisted, the DOJ concluded that formal legal intervention was necessary. On January 20, 2009, they filed suit against the state of Connecticut and its Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services. This lawsuit aimed to compel the state to address the pattern of practices at CVH that violated patients' constitutional and federal statutory rights under CRIPA. Significantly, the parties had already negotiated a comprehensive solution, as the lawsuit was filed concurrently with a settlement agreement and a joint request to dismiss the case. This strategic move allowed for an immediate resolution, bypassing protracted litigation, and enabling swift implementation of reforms under judicial oversight. Judge Alvin W. Thompson approved this settlement on July 8, 2009, conditionally closing the case while retaining the court's power to enforce the agreement.

The settlement itself was a detailed blueprint for reform. Connecticut committed to a wide array of practice changes and a period of supervised operation. The state agreed to uphold professional standards of care, focusing on symptom amelioration, rehabilitation, and patient well-being. It mandated an environment of safety and respect, integrated treatment plans, and interdisciplinary staff teams, all designed to enhance patient safety and reduce the pervasive risk of harm and suicide. This 48-month period of supervised implementation was intended to ensure the state's accountability and lasting systemic change.

As the supervised period progressed, on September 25, 2013, the state sought and received court approval for a notice of substantial compliance with certain terms, along with an extension, indicating the ongoing complexity of achieving full reform. Ultimately, on May 22, 2015, the state moved to terminate the agreement, asserting that it had achieved substantial compliance with the settlement's terms. The court approved this request, thereby ending its formal oversight and enforcement authority.

Yet, the historical record reveals a somber epilogue. Despite the legal intervention and the state's declaration of compliance, reports as late as mid-2017 suggested that patients at CVH continued to endure widespread abuse. This culminated on September 6, 2017, with the arrests of nine CVH employees on charges of cruelty to persons and disorderly conduct, with news reports detailing horrific instances of violence, humiliation, and sexual harassment. This unfortunate turn of events underscores the persistent challenges in safeguarding vulnerable populations, even after significant legal efforts.

2.transformed_text:
The central legal conflict in this case revolved around whether the State of Connecticut was adequately protecting the constitutional and federal statutory rights of patients at Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), its largest psychiatric facility. Following an investigation that revealed serious deficiencies, the Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against the state, which was promptly resolved by a court-approved settlement agreement.

The Department of Justice's investigation, initiated in 2005, found that CVH patients were inadequately protected from harm and undue restraints, received deficient psychiatric and psychological services, and lacked sufficient discharge planning. These findings led the DOJ to conclude that formal intervention was necessary to compel the state to uphold patients' rights under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA). The settlement, approved by the court, mandated extensive reforms. Connecticut committed to providing care based on professional standards, focusing on symptom amelioration, rehabilitation, and patient well-being. It required a safe and respectful environment, integrated treatment plans, and interdisciplinary staff teams to enhance patient safety and reduce the risk of harm and suicide. For 48 months, the state's implementation of these changes was supervised. Ultimately, in 2015, the court accepted the state's assertion of substantial compliance and ended its oversight. However, subsequent reports as late as mid-2017, culminating in the arrests of nine employees, revealed that patients continued to suffer widespread abuse, indicating the persistent challenges in safeguarding vulnerable individuals despite the legal intervention.

3.transformed_text:
Despite a significant legal intervention aimed at protecting vulnerable individuals, patients at Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), Connecticut's largest psychiatric facility, continued to suffer widespread abuse, underscoring the persistent challenges in safeguarding their rights.

Years earlier, an investigation by the Department of Justice revealed that CVH patients were inadequately protected from harm and undue restraints, received deficient psychiatric and psychological services, and lacked sufficient discharge planning. These critical findings prompted formal action, leading to an agreement that mandated extensive reforms to compel the state to uphold patients' rights. Under this agreement, Connecticut committed to providing care based on professional standards, focusing on symptom amelioration, rehabilitation, and patient well-being. It required a safe and respectful environment, integrated treatment plans, and interdisciplinary staff teams to enhance patient safety and reduce the risk of harm and suicide. The state's implementation of these changes was supervised for 48 months. While state oversight eventually concluded in 2015, based on the state's assertion of substantial compliance, subsequent reports as late as mid-2017, culminating in the arrests of nine employees, tragically revealed that patients continued to suffer widespread abuse. This outcome highlights the critical gap between official compliance and the actual, lived experience of vulnerable individuals, demonstrating that the legal intervention did not fully achieve its goal of ensuring patient safety and dignity.

4.transformed_text:
Patients living at Connecticut Valley Hospital (CVH), the largest psychiatric facility in Connecticut, faced a deeply troubling reality. They were not safe, often subjected to unnecessary restraints, received inadequate mental health care, and lacked proper plans when it was time for them to leave. In 2005, the Department of Justice, a federal group dedicated to protecting people's rights, began looking into the situation at CVH. What they uncovered by 2007 was grim: a pattern of harm and neglect.

To change this, in 2009, the Department of Justice took the state of Connecticut to task. Instead of a prolonged battle, they reached a powerful agreement, a commitment from the state to drastically improve conditions. Connecticut promised to provide care based on professional standards, focusing on helping patients recover, improving their well-being, and ensuring a safe, respectful environment. This included integrated treatment plans and dedicated staff teams to prevent harm and suicide.

For 48 months, the state's progress was closely watched. By 2015, this period of close watch ended, with the state asserting it had fulfilled its promises. Yet, heartbreaking news emerged by mid-2017: patients at CVH continued to suffer widespread abuse, leading to the arrests of nine employees. This tragic outcome highlighted a profound gap between official claims and the harsh reality faced by vulnerable individuals, showing that the initial efforts did not fully achieve their goal of ensuring safety and dignity.

original_case_data.name: Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program v. SafetyNet Youth, Inc.
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiff, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP), was Alabama's designated Protection and Advocacy provider.
special_collections: DOJ Civil Rights Division Statements of Interest
original_case_data.summary:
On October 25, 2013, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP) filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the Southern District of Alabama. The plaintiff, which served as Alabama’s designated protection and advocacy program for people with disabilities, sued SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) under the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986 (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program of 1993 (PAIR). The plaintiff alleged that SafetyNet had unlawfully failed to allow it, as Alabama’s Protection and Advocacy (P&A) provider, to monitor the defendant's facilities. Specifically, the plaintiff alleged that the defendant had failed to grant ADAP access to facilities used for SafetyNet Academy, a program operated by the defendant for male youths with emotional or behavioral disabilities. The plaintiff claimed that, despite several attempts to explain to the staff at SafetyNet Academy why they were required by law to allow ADAP into all of the Academy's facilities for monitoring and investigation purposes, the defendant repeatedly refused to grant ADAP access to what it referred to as its Moderate Program. The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to compel the SafetyNet Academy to grant them reasonable access to the facilities.

On December 2, 2013 – the same day the defendant filed an answer denying that it was required to allow the plaintiff access to its Moderate Program – it also filed a third-party complaint against the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). SafetyNet claimed that, because it had acted on the advice and counsel of DHR, which served as its licensing authority, any potential violations on its own part were caused by DHR. On this basis, it sought indemnification from DHR for any recovery that may be received by the plaintiff against SafetyNet.

Unable to agree on terms of a settlement, the parties proceeded with discovery. On September 19, 2014, all three parties moved for summary judgment. While the plaintiff held onto its position that it was allowed access to all of SafetyNet Academy’s programs, the defendants argued that because the individuals in the Moderate Program had moderate (rather than severe) mental illness, they were excluded from P&A protection.

Shortly afterward, on October 14, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) submitted a statement of interest supporting the plaintiff’s position that summary judgment against the defendants was appropriate. The DOJ asserted that the defendant’s facilities at SafetyNet Academy fell squarely within the parameters of PAIMI regulations and, as such, the plaintiff must be granted reasonable unrestricted access to all of the academy’s programs.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande awarded summary judgment to the plaintiff, denying both defendants’ requests for summary judgment as well as SafetyNet’s request for indemnification and contribution against DHR. The judge found that, as a facility that provided residential treatment for individuals with mental illness and other disabilities, PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR applied to SafetyNet Academy. Rejecting defendants’ assertion that individuals with moderate mental illness may be excluded from P&A protection, she emphasized that the protections offered by these laws were intended to be broad in scope and did not define P&A access “one resident at a time.” Accordingly, Judge Grande held that ADAP was authorized to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs and must be allowed reasonable access by law and awarded declaratory and permanent injunctive relief to the plaintiff. She also ordered ADAP and SafetyNet to meet and prepare a protocol for ADAP’s monitoring and investigation visits. Finally, the order denied SafetyNet’s request for indemnification against DHR and held that each party should bear its own attorneys’ fees and costs. 65 F.Supp.3d 1312.

The parties met and submitted access protocol on January 30, 2015. In addition to describing ADAP’s scope of access to SafetyNet and its records, the protocol outlined procedures ADAP may follow should SafetyNet deny or delay access to its facilities in the future.

Also following the grant of summary judgment, ADAP submitted a motion for reconsideration of the court’s denial of attorneys’ fees and costs. On February 11, 2015, Judge Grande issued an order awarding the plaintiff filing fees as the prevailing party. However, the order denied the plaintiff attorneys’ fees, citing a failure to raise an applicable exception to the American Rule stating that litigants are generally expected to bear their own attorneys’ fees and costs. 2015 WL 566946.
original_case_data.summary_short: In the Southern District of Alabama in October 2013, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program brought this lawsuit against SafetyNet, Inc., claiming that the defendant had failed to allow the plaintiff access to its facilities as required by the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986 (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program of 1993 (PAIR). In December 2013, the defendant filed a third-party complaint against the Alabama Department of Human Resources. After all three parties moved for summary judgment, on December 12, 2014,the court granted the plaintiff’s motion, holding that the defendant was required to grant the plaintiff access to its facilities by law and awarding injunctive and declaratory relief to the plaintiff.

On October 25, 2013, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP), serving as Alabama’s designated protection and advocacy program for people with disabilities, initiated this lawsuit in the District Court for the Southern District of Alabama. ADAP sued SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) under the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986 (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program of 1993 (PAIR). ADAP alleged that SafetyNet, as the operator of SafetyNet Academy—a program for male youths with emotional or behavioral disabilities—unlawfully failed to allow ADAP, as the state’s P&A provider, to monitor its facilities. Specifically, ADAP claimed SafetyNet repeatedly refused to grant access to what it referred to as its “Moderate Program,” despite several attempts by ADAP to explain the legal requirement for monitoring and investigation across all Academy facilities. ADAP sought declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to compel SafetyNet Academy to grant reasonable access.

On December 2, 2013, SafetyNet filed an answer denying required access to its Moderate Program and simultaneously filed a third-party complaint against the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). SafetyNet contended that DHR, as its licensing authority, caused any potential violations by providing advice and counsel, and therefore sought indemnification from DHR for any recovery obtained by ADAP.

Following unsuccessful settlement negotiations, the parties proceeded with discovery, after which all three parties moved for summary judgment. ADAP maintained its position that it was legally entitled to access all of SafetyNet Academy’s programs. Conversely, the defendants argued that individuals within the Moderate Program, possessing moderate rather than severe mental illness, were excluded from P&A protection.

Shortly thereafter, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) submitted a statement of interest supporting ADAP's position that summary judgment against the defendants was appropriate. The DOJ asserted that SafetyNet Academy facilities fell squarely within the parameters of PAIMI regulations, thereby mandating reasonable unrestricted access to all academy programs.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande awarded summary judgment to ADAP, denying both defendants’ requests for summary judgment, as well as SafetyNet’s request for indemnification and contribution against DHR. The court determined that PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR applied to SafetyNet Academy, given its status as a facility providing residential treatment for individuals with mental illness and other disabilities. The judge rejected the defendants’ assertion that individuals with moderate mental illness could be excluded from P&A protection, emphasizing that these laws’ protections were intended to be broad in scope and did not define P&A access “one resident at a time.” Accordingly, Judge Grande held that ADAP was authorized to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs and must be allowed reasonable access by law, awarding declaratory and permanent injunctive relief to the plaintiff. The order further directed ADAP and SafetyNet to meet and prepare a protocol for ADAP’s monitoring and investigation visits. Finally, the court denied SafetyNet’s request for indemnification against DHR and held that each party should bear its own attorneys’ fees and costs. 65 F.Supp.3d 1312.

Subsequent to the court’s order, the parties met and submitted an access protocol. This protocol not only described ADAP’s scope of access to SafetyNet and its records, but also outlined specific procedures ADAP could follow should SafetyNet deny or delay access to its facilities in the future.

Also following the grant of summary judgment, ADAP submitted a motion for reconsideration of the court’s denial of attorneys’ fees and costs. On February 11, 2015, Judge Grande issued an order awarding ADAP filing fees as the prevailing party. However, the order denied ADAP attorneys’ fees, citing its failure to raise an applicable exception to the American Rule, which generally dictates that litigants bear their own attorneys’ fees and costs. 2015 WL 566946.

*   ADAP, as Alabama’s designated protection and advocacy program, initiated this lawsuit under the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program (PAIR), alleging SafetyNet, operator of SafetyNet Academy for youths with emotional or behavioral disabilities, unlawfully refused ADAP access to its "Moderate Program." *   SafetyNet had denied required access and simultaneously filed a third-party complaint against the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR), seeking indemnification for potential violations caused by DHR’s advice. The court denied SafetyNet’s requests for summary judgment, as well as its request for indemnification and contribution against DHR, aligning with the U.S. Department of Justice’s statement of interest supporting ADAP's position.
*   While the court initially held each party should bear its own attorneys’ fees and costs, Judge Grande later awarded ADAP filing fees as the prevailing party but denied attorneys’ fees, citing ADAP’s failure to raise an applicable exception to the American Rule, which generally requires litigants to bear their own legal expenses.

On October 25, 2013, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP) sued SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) in federal court. ADAP, which is Alabama’s official program for protecting and advocating for people with disabilities, claimed SafetyNet violated several laws designed to protect people with disabilities: the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program (PAIR). ADAP alleged that SafetyNet illegally prevented it, as Alabama's P&A provider, from monitoring SafetyNet's facilities. Specifically, ADAP claimed SafetyNet did not allow access to its SafetyNet Academy facilities, a program for young men with emotional or behavioral disabilities. ADAP stated that despite repeated attempts to explain the legal requirement for access to all Academy facilities for monitoring and investigation, SafetyNet repeatedly denied access to its "Moderate Program." ADAP asked the court to declare its right to access and issue a preliminary order (injunction) to force SafetyNet Academy to allow it reasonable access.

On December 2, 2013, the same day SafetyNet filed its response denying it had to allow ADAP access to its Moderate Program, it also sued the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). SafetyNet argued that DHR, its licensing authority, had advised it. Therefore, any wrongdoing by SafetyNet was DHR's fault. Based on this, SafetyNet asked DHR to cover any money ADAP might win against SafetyNet.

The parties could not agree on a settlement, so they moved forward with exchanging information (discovery). On September 19, 2014, all three parties asked the court for a judgment in their favor without a full trial (summary judgment). ADAP maintained its right to access all SafetyNet Academy programs. SafetyNet and DHR, however, argued that individuals in the Moderate Program had only moderate, not severe, mental illness, and therefore were not covered by P&A protections.

Soon after, on October 14, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a statement supporting ADAP. The DOJ agreed that the court should rule in ADAP's favor without a trial. The DOJ stated that SafetyNet Academy's facilities clearly fell under PAIMI rules. This meant ADAP must be given reasonable, unrestricted access to all of the academy's programs.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande ruled in favor of ADAP, granting it summary judgment. She denied SafetyNet's and DHR's requests for summary judgment, and also denied SafetyNet's request for DHR to cover its costs. The judge determined that SafetyNet Academy, as a residential treatment facility for people with mental illness and other disabilities, was covered by PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR. She rejected the argument that individuals with moderate mental illness were excluded from P&A protection. She stressed that these laws were meant to offer broad protection and did not limit P&A access based on each individual resident. Therefore, Judge Grande ruled that ADAP had the authority to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs and must be given reasonable access by law. She issued a declaration of rights and a permanent order (injunction) in ADAP's favor. She also ordered ADAP and SafetyNet to create a formal plan (protocol) for ADAP's monitoring and investigation visits. Finally, the order again denied SafetyNet's request for DHR to cover its costs. The judge also ruled that each party would pay their own legal fees and expenses.

The parties met and submitted the access plan on January 30, 2015. This plan detailed ADAP's access to SafetyNet's facilities and records. It also outlined steps ADAP could take if SafetyNet denied or delayed access in the future.

After the summary judgment ruling, ADAP asked the court to reconsider its decision to deny legal fees and costs. On February 11, 2015, Judge Grande issued an order granting ADAP its filing fees, as it was the winning party. However, she denied ADAP's request for attorneys' fees. She noted that ADAP had not shown an exception to the "American Rule," which generally requires each party to pay their own legal fees and costs.

Specifically, ADAP said SafetyNet wouldn't let it into SafetyNet Academy, a program for young men with emotional or behavioral issues. ADAP stated that even after explaining its legal right to access all parts of the Academy for monitoring and investigations, SafetyNet repeatedly refused to let it into a specific part called the "Moderate Program." ADAP asked the court to officially declare its right to access and to issue a temporary court order, called a preliminary injunction, to force SafetyNet Academy to allow it reasonable access.

On December 2, 2013, the same day SafetyNet filed its response saying it didn't have to let ADAP into its Moderate Program, it also sued the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). SafetyNet argued that DHR, which gives it its operating license, had given it advice. So, SafetyNet claimed any mistakes it made were DHR's fault. Because of this, SafetyNet asked DHR to pay for any damages or costs ADAP might win against SafetyNet; this is called seeking "indemnification."

The parties couldn't agree to settle the case, so they moved ahead with exchanging information, a process called "discovery." On September 19, 2014, all three parties asked the court to rule in their favor without a full trial, a request known as "summary judgment." ADAP insisted it had the right to access all of SafetyNet Academy's programs. SafetyNet and DHR, however, argued that the people in the Moderate Program had only moderate, not severe, mental illness, and therefore weren't covered by the laws protecting people with disabilities.

Soon after, on October 14, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a statement supporting ADAP's side. The DOJ agreed that the court should rule in ADAP's favor without needing a trial. The DOJ stated that SafetyNet Academy's facilities clearly fell under the rules of the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act. This meant ADAP must be given reasonable, unrestricted access to all of the academy's programs.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande ruled in favor of ADAP, granting its request for summary judgment. She denied similar requests from SafetyNet and DHR, and also rejected SafetyNet's request for DHR to pay its costs. The judge decided that SafetyNet Academy, as a place that provides residential treatment for people with mental illness and other disabilities, was covered by the federal laws protecting people with disabilities (PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR). She rejected the argument that people with moderate mental illness were not covered by these protections. She emphasized that these laws were designed to offer wide-ranging protection and did not limit access based on each individual resident's specific condition.

Therefore, Judge Grande ruled that ADAP had the legal power to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs and must be given reasonable access, as required by law. She issued an official declaration of ADAP's rights and a permanent court order, known as a permanent injunction, in ADAP's favor. She also ordered ADAP and SafetyNet to create a formal plan, or "protocol," for ADAP's monitoring and investigation visits. Finally, the order again denied SafetyNet's request for DHR to cover its costs. The judge also ruled that each party would pay their own legal fees and expenses.

The parties met and submitted the access plan on January 30, 2015. This plan spelled out how ADAP would access SafetyNet's facilities and records. It also described steps ADAP could take if SafetyNet denied or delayed access in the future.

After the summary judgment ruling, ADAP asked the court to rethink its decision to deny legal fees and costs. On February 11, 2015, Judge Grande issued an order granting ADAP its filing fees, since it was the winning party. However, she denied ADAP's request for its lawyers' fees. She noted that ADAP had not shown a reason to make an exception to what's called the "American Rule," which generally means each side in a lawsuit pays their own legal fees and costs.

Imagine a group whose job it is to stick up for students with disabilities, making sure they get the support and rights they're supposed to have. That's kind of like the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP). In 2013, ADAP took SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) to court. ADAP claimed SafetyNet wasn't following federal laws that protect people with disabilities, especially those with mental health challenges. Think of these laws as a set of rules, like the 'Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act,' that make sure people with disabilities are treated fairly.

ADAP said SafetyNet was breaking the rules by not letting them visit and check on their facilities. Specifically, ADAP wanted to get into SafetyNet Academy, a place for young men dealing with emotional or behavioral issues. ADAP explained that the law gave them the right to visit all areas of the Academy to make sure everything was okay. But SafetyNet kept saying 'no,' especially when it came to a specific part called the 'Moderate Program.' So, ADAP asked the judge to officially say they had the right to go in, and to issue a special temporary order – like a principal telling a student they *have* to follow a rule *right now* – to force SafetyNet to let them in.

On the very day SafetyNet told the court it wouldn't let ADAP into the Moderate Program, SafetyNet also turned around and sued another group: the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). Think of DHR as the state agency that gives places like SafetyNet their 'okay to operate' license. SafetyNet argued that DHR had given them advice, and if SafetyNet did anything wrong, it was DHR's fault. So, SafetyNet basically said, 'If ADAP wins and we have to pay, DHR should be the one to pay for it!' This is like saying, 'If I get in trouble for something my teacher told me to do, my teacher should pay the consequences.'

Since everyone couldn't agree to a peaceful solution, the case moved forward. They started 'discovery,' which is like each side gathering all the facts and evidence they can find. Then, in September 2014, all three groups asked the judge to make a decision without needing a full trial – this is called 'summary judgment.' ADAP stuck to its belief that it had the right to visit all parts of SafetyNet Academy. But SafetyNet and DHR argued that the young men in the Moderate Program only had 'moderate' mental health issues, not 'severe' ones, so they shouldn't be covered by the disability protection laws.

Not long after, a big player stepped in: the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). Think of the DOJ as the federal government's main law enforcement arm. They filed a statement saying they agreed with ADAP and that the judge should rule in ADAP's favor without a trial. The DOJ said SafetyNet Academy clearly fell under the rules of the 'Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act,' meaning ADAP *had* to be allowed reasonable access to *all* of the academy's programs, no exceptions.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande made her decision. She sided with ADAP, saying they were right and granting their request to win without a trial. She said 'no' to SafetyNet's and DHR's requests. She also rejected SafetyNet's idea that DHR should pay its bills. The judge explained that SafetyNet Academy, because it helps people with mental illness and other disabilities by providing a place for them to live and get treatment, *was* covered by those federal laws protecting people with disabilities. She didn't buy the argument that people with 'moderate' mental illness weren't protected. She stressed that these laws were meant to protect *everyone* broadly, not just those with the most severe conditions, and access shouldn't be limited based on what each person's specific situation was.

So, Judge Grande officially ruled that ADAP had the legal authority – like a green light from the law – to check on all of SafetyNet Academy's programs and *had* to be given reasonable access. She issued an official statement confirming ADAP's rights and a permanent court order – like a rule that stays in place forever – telling SafetyNet to comply. She also told ADAP and SafetyNet to work together to create a formal plan, or 'protocol,' for how ADAP's visits would happen. And once again, the judge said 'no' to SafetyNet's request for DHR to pay its costs. The judge also decided that, generally, each side would have to pay for their own lawyers and court expenses.

The two sides did meet and turned in their access plan in January 2015. This plan clearly explained how ADAP would get into SafetyNet's buildings and look at their records. It also laid out what ADAP could do if SafetyNet ever tried to block or slow down their access again.

After winning the main part of the case, ADAP asked the court to reconsider its decision about legal fees. In February 2015, Judge Grande said ADAP could get back the money it paid to file the lawsuit, since they won. But she still said 'no' to ADAP's request for their lawyers' fees. She explained that ADAP hadn't shown a special reason to go against something called the 'American Rule,' which basically says that, most of the time, everyone involved in a lawsuit has to pay for their own lawyers and other legal costs, win or lose.

0.text:
On October 25, 2013, the Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP) filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the Southern District of Alabama. The plaintiff, which served as Alabama’s designated protection and advocacy program for people with disabilities, sued SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) under the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986 (PAIMI), the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 (PADD Act), and the Protection and Advocacy of Individual Rights Program of 1993 (PAIR). The plaintiff alleged that SafetyNet had unlawfully failed to allow it, as Alabama’s Protection and Advocacy (P&A) provider, to monitor the defendant's facilities. Specifically, the plaintiff alleged that the defendant had failed to grant ADAP access to facilities used for SafetyNet Academy, a program operated by the defendant for male youths with emotional or behavioral disabilities. The plaintiff claimed that, despite several attempts to explain to the staff at SafetyNet Academy why they were required by law to allow ADAP into all of the Academy's facilities for monitoring and investigation purposes, the defendant repeatedly refused to grant ADAP access to what it referred to as its Moderate Program. The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to compel the SafetyNet Academy to grant them reasonable access to the facilities.

On December 2, 2013 – the same day the defendant filed an answer denying that it was required to allow the plaintiff access to its Moderate Program – it also filed a third-party complaint against the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR). SafetyNet claimed that, because it had acted on the advice and counsel of DHR, which served as its licensing authority, any potential violations on its own part were caused by DHR. On this basis, it sought indemnification from DHR for any recovery that may be received by the plaintiff against SafetyNet.

Unable to agree on terms of a settlement, the parties proceeded with discovery. On September 19, 2014, all three parties moved for summary judgment. While the plaintiff held onto its position that it was allowed access to all of SafetyNet Academy’s programs, the defendants argued that because the individuals in the Moderate Program had moderate (rather than severe) mental illness, they were excluded from P&A protection.

Shortly afterward, on October 14, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) submitted a statement of interest supporting the plaintiff’s position that summary judgment against the defendants was appropriate. The DOJ asserted that the defendant’s facilities at SafetyNet Academy fell squarely within the parameters of PAIMI regulations and, as such, the plaintiff must be granted reasonable unrestricted access to all of the academy’s programs.

On December 12, 2014, Judge Callie V.S. Grande awarded summary judgment to the plaintiff, denying both defendants’ requests for summary judgment as well as SafetyNet’s request for indemnification and contribution against DHR. The judge found that, as a facility that provided residential treatment for individuals with mental illness and other disabilities, PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR applied to SafetyNet Academy. Rejecting defendants’ assertion that individuals with moderate mental illness may be excluded from P&A protection, she emphasized that the protections offered by these laws were intended to be broad in scope and did not define P&A access “one resident at a time.” Accordingly, Judge Grande held that ADAP was authorized to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs and must be allowed reasonable access by law and awarded declaratory and permanent injunctive relief to the plaintiff. She also ordered ADAP and SafetyNet to meet and prepare a protocol for ADAP’s monitoring and investigation visits. Finally, the order denied SafetyNet’s request for indemnification against DHR and held that each party should bear its own attorneys’ fees and costs. 65 F.Supp.3d 1312.

The parties met and submitted access protocol on January 30, 2015. In addition to describing ADAP’s scope of access to SafetyNet and its records, the protocol outlined procedures ADAP may follow should SafetyNet deny or delay access to its facilities in the future.

Also following the grant of summary judgment, ADAP submitted a motion for reconsideration of the court’s denial of attorneys’ fees and costs. On February 11, 2015, Judge Grande issued an order awarding the plaintiff filing fees as the prevailing party. However, the order denied the plaintiff attorneys’ fees, citing a failure to raise an applicable exception to the American Rule stating that litigants are generally expected to bear their own attorneys’ fees and costs. 2015 WL 566946.

1.transformed_text:
The Alabama Disabilities Advocacy Program (ADAP), serving as the state's designated advocate for people with disabilities, initiated legal action in October 2013. Their purpose was to compel SafetyNet Youthcare, Inc. (SafetyNet) to grant them access to its facilities, specifically SafetyNet Academy, a program for male youths with emotional or behavioral disabilities. ADAP believed that SafetyNet was unlawfully impeding its ability to monitor and investigate the facilities, a right granted by federal laws like PAIMI, PADD, and PAIR. Despite repeated attempts to explain their legal mandate, ADAP found SafetyNet unwilling to allow access to what it termed its "Moderate Program," prompting ADAP to seek a court order to ensure reasonable access.

SafetyNet, in response, not only denied ADAP's claims, asserting it was not required to permit access to its "Moderate Program," but also strategically brought the Alabama Department of Human Resources (DHR) into the case. SafetyNet argued that if any wrongdoing occurred, DHR, as its licensing authority, was responsible due to the advice it had provided, thereby seeking to shift potential financial responsibility.

When efforts to reach a settlement proved futile, all parties sought a definitive court ruling without the need for a full trial by moving for summary judgment in September 2014. ADAP maintained its unwavering position that it possessed the right to monitor all of SafetyNet Academy's programs. Conversely, SafetyNet and DHR contended that individuals with "moderate" mental illness were outside the scope of the protection and advocacy laws, aiming to limit ADAP's reach.

Adding significant weight to ADAP's argument, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) intervened in October 2014, submitting a statement that strongly supported ADAP's stance. The DOJ underscored that SafetyNet Academy's facilities clearly fell under federal regulations, necessitating unrestricted access for ADAP to all programs.

Ultimately, in December 2014, the court sided decisively with ADAP. The judge ruled that SafetyNet Academy, as a residential treatment facility for individuals with mental and other disabilities, was indeed subject to the comprehensive federal protection laws. The court rejected the defendants' narrow interpretation, emphasizing the broad intent of these laws to protect all individuals within such facilities, not just those with "severe" conditions. This judgment affirmed ADAP's authority to monitor all SafetyNet Academy programs, mandating reasonable access and ordering the parties to establish a clear protocol for future visits. The court also denied SafetyNet's attempt to transfer liability to DHR, requiring each party to bear its own legal costs.

Following this ruling, ADAP and SafetyNet collaboratively developed and submitted an access protocol in January 2015. This agreement not only defined ADAP's scope of access to facilities and records but also established clear procedures for ADAP to follow if future access issues arose, ensuring the court's mandate was practically implemented.

ADAP later sought reconsideration regarding the denial of attorneys' fees, aiming to recover the costs incurred in pursuing this vital advocacy work. While the court awarded ADAP filing fees as the prevailing party in February 2015, it ultimately denied attorneys' fees, citing the general rule that litigants typically cover their own legal expenses unless specific exceptions apply.

original_case_data.name: Sisters of Life v. Bassett
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: The Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order of religious sisters located in New York, New York.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
This matter has to do with Assembly Bill A5499/Senate Bill S470 (the “Act”) in New York State, which passed in June 2022. The Act was one of six statutes billed as the “nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights” by New York Governor Kathy Hochul. It authorized the state Commissioner of Health to conduct a study and issue a report examining the unmet health and resource needs facing pregnant women in New York.

The Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order of religious sisters located in New York, New York, filed this lawsuit against the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health on September 2, 2022. The Sisters of Life operate a crisis pregnancy center offering resources for pregnant women at their Visitation Mission in lower Manhattan. They claimed that the Act imposed intrusive and burdensome disclosure requirements, enforced by financial penalties, in violation of the First Amendment's Establishment Clause as well as the First Amendment rights to free speech, free exercise, assembly, and association in addition to the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable search and seizure. Sisters of Life requested that the Court declare the Act unconstitutional on its face and as it applied, and sought a permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement, as well as attorney’s fees and costs. 

On September 16, 2022, Sisters of Life filed a motion for a preliminary injunction that would enjoin enforcement of the Act during the litigation. 

On October 7, 2022, the parties filed a joint request to stay the litigation while they continued to discuss scheduling matters. The Court agreed to stay the litigation until January 10, 2023. On January 18, 2023 this stay was extended until April 17, 2023 after the parties jointly filed requesting an extension of the stay period. The New York State Department of Health advised that it was continuing to make progress on implementation of the statute and needed more time to determine the scope and timing of information requests under the statute. The parties agreed that in light of this, an extension of the stay period was the most efficient course of action for the parties and for the Court. 

On January 27, 2023 the case was reassigned to Judge Jennifer H. Rearden. The stay period was extended multiple times. 

On November 3, 2023 the parties submitted to the court a proposed Stipulation and Order of Settlement. On November 8, 2023 the order of settlement was stipulated and agreed to. The parties agreed, and Court approved, that all claims asserted by Plaintiff were to be dismissed, with prejudice and without payments, attorney's fees, costs, disbursements, or expenses, pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a). Each party agreed to bear their own attorney's fees and costs. Defendant agreed not to take any enforcement action of any kind against Plaintiff based on Plaintiff's nonresponse to or noncompliance with any survey, document request, or information request of any kind authorized by or issued by Defendant pursuant to the statute. Per the agreement, the court was to retain jurisdiction until the Defendant's authority to request data ended via the publication of he report. Judge Rearden directed that the case be closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: This matter was brought by The Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order of religious sisters located in New York City. The Plaintiff challenged a NY State Act, one of six statutes billed as the “nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights” by New York Governor Hochul. The Plaintiff claimed that the Act imposed intrusive and burdensome disclosure requirements and sought a permanent injunction prohibiting the enforcement of the Act. On November 8, 2023 the order of settlement was stipulated and agreed to. The parties agreed, and Court approved, that all claims asserted by Plaintiff were to be dismissed, with prejudice and without payments, attorney's fees, costs, disbursements, or expenses. Defendant agreed not to take any enforcement action of any kind against Plaintiff based on Plaintiff's nonresponse to or noncompliance with any survey, document request, or information request of any kind authorized by or issued by Defendant pursuant to the statute. Each party agreed to bear their own attorney's fees and costs. Judge Rearden directed the case be closed.

1.transformed_text:
This matter concerns Assembly Bill A5499/Senate Bill S470 (the “Act”) in New York State, which passed in June 2022. The Act was one of six statutes billed as the “nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights” by New York Governor Kathy Hochul. It authorized the state Commissioner of Health to conduct a study and issue a report examining the unmet health and resource needs facing pregnant women in New York.

Plaintiff Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order of religious sisters operating a crisis pregnancy center in lower Manhattan, filed suit on September 2, 2022, against the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health. Plaintiff alleged the Act imposed intrusive and burdensome disclosure requirements, enforced by financial penalties, violating their First Amendment rights (Establishment Clause, free speech, free exercise, assembly, and association) and Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable search and seizure. Plaintiff sought a declaration that the Act was unconstitutional on its face and as applied, a permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement, and attorney’s fees and costs. Plaintiff subsequently moved for a preliminary injunction to enjoin enforcement of the Act during litigation.

The parties jointly requested and were granted a stay of litigation to discuss scheduling matters. This stay was subsequently extended multiple times, as the New York State Department of Health advised it was continuing to make progress on implementation of the statute and needed more time to determine the scope and timing of information requests. The parties agreed this extension was the most efficient course of action. During this period, the case was reassigned to Judge Jennifer H. Rearden.

The parties submitted a proposed Stipulation and Order of Settlement, which was subsequently stipulated and agreed to. The Court approved the dismissal of all Plaintiff's claims with prejudice, without payments, attorney's fees, costs, disbursements, or expenses, pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a). Each party agreed to bear their own attorney's fees and costs. Defendant agreed not to take any enforcement action against Plaintiff for nonresponse or noncompliance with any survey, document, or information request authorized or issued under the statute. Per the agreement, the Court retained jurisdiction until Defendant's authority to request data ended via the report's publication. Judge Rearden directed the case be closed.

This matter concerned Assembly Bill A5499/Senate Bill S470 (the “Act”), enacted in New York State in June 2022. The Act, part of a "nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights" as described by Governor Kathy Hochul, authorized the state Commissioner of Health to study and report on unmet health and resource needs facing pregnant women in New York.

Plaintiff Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order operating a crisis pregnancy center in lower Manhattan, initiated this action on September 2, 2022, against the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health. Plaintiff alleged the Act imposed intrusive and burdensome disclosure requirements, enforced by financial penalties, violating their First Amendment rights (Establishment Clause, free speech, free exercise, assembly, and association) and Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable search and seizure. Plaintiff sought a declaration that the Act was unconstitutional on its face and as applied, a permanent injunction prohibiting its enforcement, and an award of attorney’s fees and costs. Plaintiff subsequently moved for a preliminary injunction to enjoin enforcement of the Act during litigation.

Litigation was subsequently stayed multiple times at the parties' joint request, primarily to facilitate scheduling discussions and allow the New York State Department of Health to advance its implementation efforts and define the scope and timing of information requests. During this period, the case was reassigned to Judge Jennifer H. Rearden.

The Court approved the dismissal of all Plaintiff's claims with prejudice, without payments, attorney's fees, costs, disbursements, or expenses, pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a). Each party agreed to bear their own attorney's fees and costs. Defendant agreed not to take any enforcement action against Plaintiff for nonresponse or noncompliance with any survey, document, or information request authorized or issued under the statute. Per the agreement, the Court retained jurisdiction until the Defendant's authority to request data concluded with the report's publication. Judge Rearden directed the case be closed.

They claimed that the Act imposed intrusive and burdensome disclosure requirements, enforced by financial penalties, in violation of the First Amendment's Establishment Clause as well as the First Amendment rights to free speech, free exercise, assembly, and association in addition to the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable search and seizure. Sisters of Life requested that the Court declare the Act unconstitutional on its face and as it applied, and sought a permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement, as well as attorney’s fees and costs. 

On September 16, 2022, Sisters of Life filed a motion for a preliminary injunction that would enjoin enforcement of the Act during the litigation. 

On October 7, 2022, the parties filed a joint request to stay the litigation while they continued to discuss scheduling matters. The Court agreed to stay the litigation until January 10, 2023. On January 18, 2023 this stay was extended until April 17, 2023 after the parties jointly filed requesting an extension of the stay period. The New York State Department of Health advised that it was continuing to make progress on implementation of the statute and needed more time to determine the scope and timing of information requests under the statute. The parties agreed that in light of this, an extension of the stay period was the most efficient course of action for the parties and for the Court. 

On January 27, 2023 the case was reassigned to Judge Jennifer H. Rearden. The stay period was extended multiple times. 

On November 3, 2023 the parties submitted to the court a proposed Stipulation and Order of Settlement. On November 8, 2023 the order of settlement was stipulated and agreed to. The parties agreed, and Court approved, that all claims asserted by Plaintiff were to be dismissed, with prejudice and without payments, attorney's fees, costs, disbursements, or expenses, pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a). Each party agreed to bear their own attorney's fees and costs. Defendant agreed not to take any enforcement action of any kind against Plaintiff based on Plaintiff's nonresponse to or noncompliance with any survey, document request, or information request of any kind authorized by or issued by Defendant pursuant to the statute. Per the agreement, the court was to retain jurisdiction until the Defendant's authority to request data ended via the publication of he report. Judge Rearden directed that the case be closed.

1.transformed_text:
This case is about a New York law, Assembly Bill A5499/Senate Bill S470 (the “Act”), which passed in June 2022. New York Governor Kathy Hochul described the Act as part of a “nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights.” The Act allowed the state Commissioner of Health to study and report on the unmet health and resource needs of pregnant women in New York.

The Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order of religious sisters in New York, New York, sued the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health on September 2, 2022. The Sisters of Life run a crisis pregnancy center that helps pregnant women at their Visitation Mission in lower Manhattan. They claimed the Act created strict and difficult reporting rules, backed by fines. They argued these rules violated the First Amendment's Establishment Clause, and their First Amendment rights to free speech, free exercise of religion, assembly, and association. They also claimed it violated the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches. The Sisters of Life asked the Court to rule the Act unconstitutional, both generally and in how it applied to them. They also sought a permanent order to stop the Act from being enforced, along with their legal fees and costs.

On September 16, 2022, the Sisters of Life asked the court for a preliminary injunction. This was a temporary order to stop the Act from being enforced while the lawsuit was ongoing.

On October 7, 2022, both sides jointly asked to pause the lawsuit while they discussed how to move forward with the case. The Court agreed to pause the lawsuit until January 10, 2023. On January 18, 2023, this pause was extended until April 17, 2023, after both sides jointly asked for more time. The New York State Department of Health said it was still working on putting the law into effect and needed more time to figure out what information to ask for and when. Given this, both sides agreed that extending the pause was the most efficient way for them and for the Court to proceed.

On January 27, 2023, the case was assigned to a new judge, Jennifer H. Rearden. The pause in the case was extended several more times.

On November 3, 2023, both sides gave the court a proposed settlement agreement. On November 8, 2023, the settlement agreement was formally approved. Both sides agreed, and the Court approved, that all claims made by the Sisters of Life would be dismissed permanently. This meant they could not bring these claims again, and neither side would pay the other's legal fees or costs, as allowed by court rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a)). Each side agreed to pay their own legal fees and costs. The Department of Health agreed not to take any action against the Sisters of Life if they did not respond to or comply with any surveys or information requests allowed by the Act. Under the agreement, the court would keep authority over the case until the Department of Health's power to ask for data ended when the report was published. Judge Rearden then ordered the case closed.
