New York Governor Kathy Hochul called the law a "nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights." The law allowed the state's health commissioner to study and report on the health and resource needs of pregnant women in New York that were not being met.

On September 2, 2022, the Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic group of nuns in New York City, sued the head of the New York State Department of Health. The Sisters of Life run a center in lower Manhattan called Visitation Mission, which helps pregnant women in crisis. They argued the law created strict and difficult reporting rules, with fines for not following them. They claimed these rules went against their First Amendment rights, which protect freedom of speech, religion, assembly (the right to gather), and association (the right to join groups). They also said it violated the "Establishment Clause," which means the government cannot favor one religion over others. They also argued it violated the Fourth Amendment, which protects people from unreasonable searches by the government. The Sisters of Life asked the court to declare the law unconstitutional, meaning it went against the U.S. Constitution, both in general and in how it specifically affected them. They also sought a permanent order, or "injunction," to stop the law from being put into effect, and asked for their legal fees and costs to be paid.

On September 16, 2022, the Sisters of Life asked the court for a "preliminary injunction." This is a temporary court order that would have stopped the law from being enforced while the lawsuit continued.

On October 7, 2022, both sides involved in the lawsuit jointly asked the court to "pause" the case, or put it on hold, while they talked about how to proceed. The court agreed to halt the lawsuit until January 10, 2023. On January 18, 2023, this pause was extended to April 17, 2023, after both sides again asked for more time. The New York State Department of Health said it was still working on putting the law into effect. It needed more time to figure out what information to ask for and when. Because of this, both sides agreed that extending the pause was the most efficient way for them and for the court to move forward.

On January 27, 2023, the case was assigned to a new judge, Jennifer H. Rearden. The pause in the case was extended several more times.

On November 3, 2023, both sides presented the court with a proposed agreement to settle the case. On November 8, 2023, the settlement was officially approved. Both sides agreed, and the court approved, that all claims made by the Sisters of Life would be permanently dropped. This meant the Sisters of Life could not bring these claims again in the future. Also, neither side would pay the other's legal fees or costs. Each side agreed to pay their own legal fees and costs. The Department of Health agreed not to take any action against the Sisters of Life if they chose not to respond to or follow any surveys or requests for information allowed by the law. Under the agreement, the court would keep authority over the case until the Department of Health's power to ask for data ended once the report was published. Judge Rearden then ordered the case closed.

New York Governor Kathy Hochul described this law as a "nation-leading package" designed to protect abortion and reproductive rights. The law allowed the state's main health official to study and report on what pregnant women in New York needed for their health and resources that they weren't getting.

On September 2, 2022, the Sisters of Life, a Catholic group of nuns in New York City, sued the person in charge of the New York State Department of Health. The Sisters of Life run a place in lower Manhattan called Visitation Mission, which helps pregnant women who are going through tough times. They argued that the new law created strict and complicated rules for reporting information, and that they would face fines if they didn't follow them. They claimed these rules went against their First Amendment rights, which protect important freedoms like speech, religion, and the right to gather or join groups. They also said it violated the "Establishment Clause," which is like a rule saying the government can't pick a favorite religion over others. On top of that, they argued it broke the Fourth Amendment, which protects people from unfair searches by the government. The Sisters of Life asked the court to say the law was unconstitutional, meaning it went against the U.S. Constitution, both generally and in how it specifically hurt them. They also wanted a permanent court order, called an "injunction," to stop the law from ever starting, and asked for their legal bills to be paid.

On September 16, 2022, the Sisters of Life asked the court for a "preliminary injunction." Think of this like a temporary pause button for the law that would have stopped it from being enforced while the lawsuit was still going on.

On October 7, 2022, both sides involved in the lawsuit together asked the court to hit the "pause" button on the case, or put it on hold, so they could talk about how to move forward. The court agreed to halt the lawsuit until January 10, 2023. On January 18, 2023, this pause was extended again to April 17, 2023, after both sides asked for more time. The New York State Department of Health explained they were still figuring out how to put the law into action, and they needed more time to decide what information to ask for and when. Because of this, both sides agreed that extending the pause was the smartest and most efficient way for everyone involved, including the court, to move forward.

On January 27, 2023, the case got a new judge, Jennifer H. Rearden. The case was paused several more times after that.

On November 3, 2023, both sides showed the court a proposed plan to settle the case without a full trial. On November 8, 2023, the agreement was officially approved. Both sides agreed, and the court approved, that all the complaints made by the Sisters of Life would be permanently dropped. This means they couldn't sue over these same issues again later. Also, neither side had to pay the other's legal bills; everyone agreed to pay for their own lawyers. The Department of Health promised not to punish the Sisters of Life if they chose not to answer any surveys or requests for information allowed by the law. As part of the deal, the court would keep an eye on the case until the Department of Health finished its report and no longer needed to collect data under the law. Judge Rearden then closed the case.

1.transformed_text:
New York State's Assembly Bill A5499/Senate Bill S470, passed in June 2022, emerged as a key component of Governor Kathy Hochul's "nation-leading legislative package to protect abortion and reproductive rights." This Act aimed to understand and address the unmet health and resource needs of pregnant women in New York by authorizing the Commissioner of Health to conduct a study and issue a report.

However, this legislative initiative soon faced a challenge from the Sisters of Life, a Roman Catholic order operating a crisis pregnancy center in lower Manhattan. On September 2, 2022, they initiated a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health. Their core concern was that the Act's mandated disclosure requirements, enforced by financial penalties, would intrude upon their operations and violate their fundamental First Amendment rights, including free speech, free exercise of religion, assembly, and association, as well as the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable search and seizure. The Sisters of Life sought to nullify the Act, asking the Court to declare it unconstitutional and permanently prevent its enforcement.

To immediately protect themselves from the Act's provisions while the legal battle unfolded, the Sisters of Life swiftly filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on September 16, 2022. This strategic move aimed to halt enforcement of the Act during the litigation.

As the case progressed, both parties recognized the benefit of a pause. On October 7, 2022, they jointly requested a stay of the litigation. This strategic decision was driven by the New York State Department of Health's need for more time to clarify the Act's implementation, particularly the scope and timing of its information requests. By agreeing to multiple extensions of this stay, the parties sought an efficient path forward, allowing the state to refine its approach and potentially avoid further contentious litigation.

Ultimately, the parties reached a resolution outside of a full trial. On November 3, 2023, they submitted a proposed settlement, which the Court approved on November 8, 2023. This agreement represented a pragmatic outcome for both sides. The Sisters of Life achieved their primary objective: the state committed not to enforce any survey, document, or information requests authorized by the Act against them. In return, the Sisters agreed to dismiss all their claims, with each party bearing their own legal costs. The Court retained jurisdiction until the state's authority to request data under the Act concluded with the report's publication, marking the close of this particular chapter in the legal history of reproductive rights legislation in New York.

After the Sisters of Life initiated their challenge against the Act's mandated disclosure requirements, the parties engaged in a period of negotiation and pauses in their dispute, ultimately reaching an agreement.

The resolution, approved by the court, provided a pragmatic outcome for both sides. The state committed not to enforce any survey, document, or information requests authorized by the Act specifically against the Sisters of Life. In return, the Sisters agreed to drop their challenge, with each party bearing their own legal expenses. original_case_data.name: B. v. Kinsley
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on behalf of the following class: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.
original_case_data.summary:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on behalf of a class of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health. The plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld. 

The plaintiffs asserted that the defendants’ actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in child welfare custody by unnecessarily segregating them from their home communities and placing them in heavily restrictive, and often clinically inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). The plaintiffs requested class-wide relief and asked the Court to certify the putative class and award permanent injunctive relief.  

The plaintiffs sought class certification for those meeting the following criteria: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, removing one of the named plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim and lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The United States filed a statement of interest in support of the plaintiffs' claims on April 21, 2023. The US argued that 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment professionals in order to establish that integrated settings were appropriate; 2) the children in state custody did not need to allege that their custodians chose community-based care; 3) pending state court proceedings about whether children should be placed in PRTFs did not prevent the plaintiffs from bringing these claims of unnecessary segregation; and 4) the plaintiffs had standing to bring claims against DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. 2024 WL 1350071. The Court held that the Plaintiffs had established standing and that their allegations met the requirements of L.C. v. Olmstead. Under Olmstead, community placement is required when: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) “the transfer from institutional care to a less restrictive setting is not opposed by the affected individual;” and (3) “the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.”

The Court found that on the facts alleged, though some of the plaintiffs were frequently institutionalized, it was because of a lack of community-based alternatives, not because they required institutionalization, so the plaintiffs had still sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were allegedly at serious risk of being institutionalized, which is also covered by Olmstead. Second, the Court held that Olmstead did not require a minor to allege that their custodian requested community placement: the plaintiffs alleged that they desired community-based services, meeting the second Olmstead prong. Third, the Court held that plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, stating that any inquiry into the effectiveness of the state’s plan for community-based services was not necessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the court held that the Plaintiffs’ claims were not barred by issue preclusion based on state court hearings because the state court hearings were based on individual placements and not the systemic failures alleged here. 

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.
original_case_data.summary_short: Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on December 6, 2022 in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina on behalf of a class of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health needs against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act by institutionalizing children instead of providing community-based care. On March 29, 2024, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. As of April 2024, the case is ongoing.

The plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld. 

The plaintiffs asserted that the defendants’ actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in child welfare custody by unnecessarily segregating them from their home communities and placing them in heavily restrictive, and often clinically inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). The plaintiffs requested class-wide relief and asked the Court to certify the putative class and award permanent injunctive relief.  

The plaintiffs sought class certification for those meeting the following criteria: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, removing one of the named plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim and lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The United States filed a statement of interest in support of the plaintiffs' claims on April 21, 2023. The US argued that 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment professionals in order to establish that integrated settings were appropriate; 2) the children in state custody did not need to allege that their custodians chose community-based care; 3) pending state court proceedings about whether children should be placed in PRTFs did not prevent the plaintiffs from bringing these claims of unnecessary segregation; and 4) the plaintiffs had standing to bring claims against DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. 2024 WL 1350071. The Court held that the Plaintiffs had established standing and that their allegations met the requirements of L.C. v. Olmstead. Under Olmstead, community placement is required when: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) “the transfer from institutional care to a less restrictive setting is not opposed by the affected individual;” and (3) “the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.”

The Court found that on the facts alleged, though some of the plaintiffs were frequently institutionalized, it was because of a lack of community-based alternatives, not because they required institutionalization, so the plaintiffs had still sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were allegedly at serious risk of being institutionalized, which is also covered by Olmstead. Second, the Court held that Olmstead did not require a minor to allege that their custodian requested community placement: the plaintiffs alleged that they desired community-based services, meeting the second Olmstead prong. Third, the Court held that plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, stating that any inquiry into the effectiveness of the state’s plan for community-based services was not necessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the court held that the Plaintiffs’ claims were not barred by issue preclusion based on state court hearings because the state court hearings were based on individual placements and not the systemic failures alleged here. 

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

1.transformed_text:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights sued on behalf of a group of North Carolina foster youth with mental and behavioral health needs. The plaintiffs filed their case in the federal court in North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld.

The plaintiffs claimed that DHHS's actions broke the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Specifically, they alleged that DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in foster care. They said DHHS was wrongly separating these children from their home communities and placing them in very strict, and often unsuitable, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). The plaintiffs asked the court to grant relief for the entire group. They also requested the court officially recognize the group as a class and issue a permanent order to stop the alleged discrimination.

The plaintiffs wanted the court to approve the class for children who met these conditions: (a) children currently or soon to be in North Carolina foster care, under the care of a North Carolina county social services department; (b) who have a mental condition that significantly limits a major life activity, or a history of such a condition; and (c) who are wrongly placed in a PRTF or are at high risk of being placed there.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs updated their complaint, removing one of the original plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants asked the court to dismiss the case. They argued the plaintiffs' claims were not legally sound and the court lacked the authority to hear the case.

The United States government filed a statement supporting the plaintiffs' arguments on April 21, 2023. The US argued that 1) plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment experts to show that community settings were suitable; 2) children in state care did not need to claim their guardians chose community-based care; 3) ongoing state court cases about placing children in PRTFs did not stop plaintiffs from arguing they were being wrongly separated; and 4) plaintiffs had the right to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen rejected the defendants' request to dismiss the case. The Court ruled that the plaintiffs had the right to sue. It also found their claims met the standards set by the *Olmstead* Supreme Court case. Under *Olmstead*, placing individuals in community settings is required if: (1) a community placement is suitable; (2) the person does not object to moving from an institution to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the state can reasonably provide the community placement, considering its resources and the needs of other people with mental disabilities.

The Court found that based on the facts presented, some plaintiffs were often in institutions not because they needed to be, but because there were no suitable community options. This meant the plaintiffs had still adequately claimed that community placement was appropriate for them. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were reportedly at high risk of being placed there, which *Olmstead* also covers. Second, the Court ruled that *Olmstead* did not require a minor to claim their guardian asked for community placement. The plaintiffs stated they wanted community-based services, which met the second *Olmstead* condition. Third, the Court found that plaintiffs had sufficiently claimed that their community placement could be reasonably managed. It added that checking the state's plan for community services was not necessary at this early stage of the case. Finally, the court decided that the plaintiffs' claims were not blocked by previous state court decisions. This was because those state court hearings dealt with individual placements, not the widespread problems alleged in this case.

This case is still ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

2.transformed_text:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights sued on behalf of a group of North Carolina foster youth with mental and behavioral health needs. The plaintiffs filed their case in the federal court in North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld.

The plaintiffs claimed that DHHS's actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and a law called the Rehabilitation Act. They said DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in foster care. They claimed DHHS was wrongly separating these children from their home communities and placing them in very strict, often unsuitable, psychiatric treatment centers, known as PRTFs. The plaintiffs asked the court to provide help for the entire group. They also asked the court to officially recognize the group as a "class"—a legal term for a large group of people with similar issues—and issue a permanent order to stop the alleged discrimination.

The plaintiffs wanted the court to approve the class for children who met these conditions: (a) children currently or soon to be in North Carolina foster care, under the care of a North Carolina county social services department; (b) who have a mental condition that significantly limits a major life activity, or have had such a condition in the past; and (c) who are wrongly placed in a PRTF or are at high risk of being placed there.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs changed their lawsuit, removing one of the original plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants asked the court to throw out the case. They argued the plaintiffs' claims were not valid under the law, and that the court did not have the power to hear the case.

The United States government filed a statement supporting the plaintiffs' arguments on April 21, 2023. The U.S. argued that: 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment experts to show that community settings were suitable; 2) children in state care did not need to say their guardians chose community-based care; 3) ongoing state court cases about placing children in PRTFs did not stop the plaintiffs from arguing they were being wrongly separated; and 4) the plaintiffs had the right to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen rejected the defendants' request to throw out the case. The court ruled that the plaintiffs had the right to sue. It also found their claims met the standards set by a major Supreme Court case known as *Olmstead*. Under *Olmstead*, the law says people with disabilities should be placed in community settings, rather than institutions, if: (1) a community setting is suitable for them; (2) the person agrees to move from an institution to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the state can reasonably provide the community setting, considering its money and staff, and the needs of other people with mental disabilities.

The court found that based on the facts, some plaintiffs were often in institutions not because they needed to be, but because there were no suitable community options. This meant the plaintiffs had still shown enough evidence that community placement was right for them. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were reportedly at high risk of being placed there, which the *Olmstead* ruling also covers. Second, the court ruled that *Olmstead* did not require a minor to say their guardian asked for community placement. The plaintiffs stated they wanted services in their community, which met the second *Olmstead* condition. Third, the court found that plaintiffs had shown enough evidence that their community placement could be reasonably managed. It added that checking the state's plan for community services was not necessary at this early stage of the case. Finally, the court decided that the plaintiffs' claims were not blocked by previous state court decisions. This was because those state court hearings dealt with individual placements, not the widespread problems described in this case.

This case is still ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. 2024 WL 1350071. The Court held that the Plaintiffs had established standing and that their allegations met the requirements of L.C. v. Olmstead. Under Olmstead, community placement is required when: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) “the transfer from institutional care to a less restrictive setting is not opposed by the affected individual;” and (3) “the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.”

The Court found that on the facts alleged, though some of the plaintiffs were frequently institutionalized, it was because of a lack of community-based alternatives, not because they required institutionalization, so the plaintiffs had still sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were allegedly at serious risk of being institutionalized, which is also covered by Olmstead. Second, the Court held that Olmstead did not require a minor to allege that their custodian requested community placement: the plaintiffs alleged that they desired community-based services, meeting the second Olmstead prong. Third, the Court held that plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, stating that any inquiry into the effectiveness of the state’s plan for community-based services was not necessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the court held that the Plaintiffs’ claims were not barred by issue preclusion based on state court hearings because the state court hearings were based on individual placements and not the systemic failures alleged here. 

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

1.transformed_text:
In a significant legal challenge to North Carolina's child welfare system, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights initiated a lawsuit on December 6, 2022. Their purpose was to advocate for a class of North Carolina youth in foster care who live with mental and behavioral health conditions. They brought their case in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, before Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld, against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS).

The heart of their complaint was the assertion that DHHS was violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. The plaintiffs contended that the state was discriminating against children with disabilities in its care by unnecessarily isolating them from their home communities, placing them instead in highly restrictive and often clinically unsuitable psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). Their strategic aim was to secure class-wide relief, including a court order to stop these practices, ensuring these children could access community-based care. The proposed class included children in North Carolina foster care with mental impairments who were either unnecessarily institutionalized or at serious risk of such placement.

A minor refinement to their case occurred on March 6, 2023, when an amended complaint was filed, adjusting the named plaintiffs. Shortly thereafter, on March 20, the defendants, DHHS, sought to halt the proceedings entirely. Their motion to dismiss was a strategic maneuver to argue that the plaintiffs' claims lacked legal merit or that the court did not possess the authority to hear the case, thereby attempting to avoid further litigation.

The United States government, signaling its support for the plaintiffs' interpretation of federal disability law, filed a statement of interest on April 21, 2023. This intervention aimed to bolster the plaintiffs' position against the dismissal, asserting that their claims were valid and that the children had standing to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen delivered a pivotal decision, denying the defendants' motion to dismiss. This ruling was a significant victory for the plaintiffs, confirming that they had established standing to bring their claims and that their allegations met the stringent requirements set forth by the Supreme Court in *L.C. v. Olmstead*. Under *Olmstead*, the law requires community placement when: (1) it is appropriate for the individual; (2) the individual does not oppose the move from institutional care to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the placement can be reasonably accommodated, considering the State's resources and the needs of others with mental disabilities.

The Court specifically found that despite some plaintiffs' frequent institutionalization, this was due to a scarcity of community-based alternatives, not a genuine need for institutionalization, thus sufficiently alleging community placement was appropriate. Furthermore, the Court clarified that *Olmstead* did not demand that a minor's custodian request community placement, as the plaintiffs' own desire for such services fulfilled the second prong. Crucially, the Court determined that the plaintiffs had adequately alleged that their community placement could be reasonably accommodated, emphasizing that an inquiry into the state's broader plan for community-based services was not necessary at this early stage. Lastly, the court rejected the argument that state court hearings on individual placements barred this systemic challenge, distinguishing between individual circumstances and broader systemic failures.

As of April 26, 2024, this case continues, poised to address the systemic issues raised by the plaintiffs.

2.transformed_text:
At the heart of this case is the question of whether North Carolina's child welfare system unlawfully segregates foster children with mental and behavioral health conditions by placing them in restrictive psychiatric facilities instead of community-based care. Disability Rights North Carolina, the NAACP, and Children's Rights brought a lawsuit on behalf of these children, alleging that the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act; after filing an amended complaint, DHHS moved to dismiss the case, a motion the United States government opposed.

In a pivotal decision, the court denied DHHS's motion to dismiss, allowing the plaintiffs' claims to proceed. The court affirmed that the plaintiffs had established standing and adequately alleged that DHHS's practices violated the *Olmstead* standard, which requires states to provide community-based treatment for individuals with disabilities when such placement is appropriate, not opposed by the individual, and can be reasonably accommodated. The court agreed with the plaintiffs' assertion that many children were institutionalized not due to genuine clinical need, but because North Carolina failed to provide adequate community-based alternatives, thus satisfying the requirement that community placement be appropriate. It further clarified that a minor's own desire for community services, not necessarily their custodian's request, fulfilled the "no opposition" requirement. Moreover, the court found the plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that community placement could be reasonably accommodated, emphasizing that an exhaustive inquiry into the state's broader plans was not necessary at this early stage. Finally, the court rejected the argument that individual state court placement hearings precluded this broader systemic challenge, distinguishing between individual circumstances and the systemic failures alleged by the plaintiffs. This significant ruling means the lawsuit, which seeks to compel North Carolina to provide community-based care for these vulnerable children, will proceed.

3.transformed_text:
A significant decision means the challenge against North Carolina's practice of segregating foster children with mental and behavioral health conditions in institutions, instead of community care, will now move forward. Advocacy groups like Disability Rights North Carolina, the NAACP, and Children's Rights initiated this effort, arguing the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) violated disability rights laws. The state attempted to stop the case, but the court rejected their attempt, ensuring the children's claims will be heard.

This ruling affirms a critical principle: states must provide community-based treatment for individuals with disabilities when it's appropriate, desired by the individual, and can be reasonably accommodated. The court found strong evidence that many children were placed in institutions not because they needed that level of care, but because North Carolina failed to offer suitable community alternatives. Crucially, the court clarified that a child's own wish for community services is enough, regardless of what their guardians might request. It also recognized that providing community placement is feasible, dismissing arguments that a detailed state plan was needed to prove this point at this stage. Furthermore, the court made it clear that individual placement decisions in state courts do not prevent a broader challenge to systemic failures. This is a crucial step towards ensuring North Carolina provides appropriate, integrated care for its most vulnerable foster children.

4.transformed_text:
North Carolina was consistently placing foster children with mental and behavioral health conditions in institutions, separating them from their communities. Many of these vulnerable children didn't truly need such restrictive environments; they were there because the state simply didn't offer suitable community-based options. They found themselves stuck, often away from the kind of support that could truly help them thrive.

Seeing this difficult situation, advocacy groups like Disability Rights North Carolina, the NAACP, and Children's Rights stepped forward. They spoke up for these children, arguing that the state's practice was unfair and violated their fundamental rights. The state initially tried to halt these efforts, but the children's champions pushed back.

In a significant moment, the children's voices were heard. A decision ensured that their pleas for a different life would be fully considered. This meant a fundamental truth was upheld: states have a responsibility to offer care within the community for people with disabilities, especially when it's right for them and they desire it. It was recognized that providing community care was indeed possible, and crucially, that a child's own wish for this type of support was paramount, even if others disagreed. And importantly, the decision affirmed that the bigger picture of how the state cared for all these children could still be addressed, beyond individual situations. This marks a vital step towards ensuring North Carolina's most vulnerable foster children receive the integrated, community-based care they truly deserve.

original_case_data.name: U.S. v. Oklahoma
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On December 15, 2006, the United States filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the state of Oklahoma and its officials and subgroups responsible for operation of the L.E. Rader Center ("Rader") juvenile detention facility. The complaint, as amended on May 4, 2007, alleged that the defendants (1) denied Rader's residents their rights to protection from harm from staff, from other residents, and from improper administration of psychotropic drugs; (2) provided inadequate mental health care at Rader, particularly as to screening, assessment, treatment and transition planning, and psychiatric and psychological services; and (3) failed to provide required special education services to qualifying Rader residents. Represented by Department of Justice Civil Rights Division attorneys, the federal government initiated the action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141, the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The amended complaint alleged that the state defendants' conduct violated the Fourteenth Amendment, as well as Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 794, and related regulations, and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1401.

The case, assigned to District Judge Gregory K. Frizzell, prompted motion and discovery practice resulting in several June 2007, unpublished orders by Magistrate Judge Frank H. McCarthy. These addressed matters such as protective orders to keep disclosed information about residents confidential; scheduling of on-site inspections at Rader by the plaintiff's counsel and expert consultants; who would bear the cost of security escorts during the visits (the United States, said the magistrate); and whether interviews conducted during the visits would have to be recorded (they would).

In June 2008, a settlement was reached and on September 9, 2008, the court (Judge Frizzell) entered an order incorporating the consent decree. The consent decree included resolutions about protecting juvenile residents from harm, prevention of suicide and self-harm, mental health care, and special education claims, and was set to expire three years from the date it was signed.

In September 2011, a little over a week before the consent decree was set to expire, the U.S. filed an emergency motion to modify the decree. The U.S. alleged that since Rader was closed by the state in 2011, there had been several incidents at two "replacement" facilities. The U.S. alleged that the defendants had not given them full access to investigate the incidents. The U.S. wanted the consent decree modified to extend to these other facilities so that the incidents could be investigated with the support of the court. The defendants objected, arguing that Rader was the only facility under the order and that the two facilities were not replacements as defined in the consent decree. The court agreed with the defendants, finding that the separate, pre-existing juvenile centers were not replacements under the terms of the consent decree. The defendants then moved to dismiss the case, citing the expiration of the consent decree, which the court granted on November 18, 2011.The case was dismissed with prejudice. 

This case is now closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: On December 15, 2006, the United States filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the state of Oklahoma and its officials and subgroups responsible for operation of the L.E. Rader Center ("Rader") juvenile detention facility.  Represented by Department of Justice Civil Rights Division attorneys, the federal government initiated the action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141, the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994.  The amended complaint alleged that the state defendants' conduct violated the Fourteenth Amendment, as well as Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 794, and related regulations, and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1401.  A consent decree was entered in 2008 with a term of three years.  The case is now closed, despite plaintiffs' efforts to extend the consent decree after the defendants closed the Rader facility and allegedly refused to abide by the decree with respect to incidents reported at centers plaintiffs argued constituted "replacement facilities" under the decree.

1.transformed_text:
On December 15, 2006, the United States filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the state of Oklahoma and officials operating the L.E. Rader Center ("Rader") juvenile detention facility. The complaint, amended on May 4, 2007, alleged that the defendants (1) denied Rader's residents rights to protection from harm by staff, other residents, and improper psychotropic drug administration; (2) provided inadequate mental health care, particularly regarding screening, assessment, treatment, and psychiatric and psychological services; and (3) failed to provide required special education services to qualifying residents. The federal government, represented by Department of Justice Civil Rights Division attorneys, initiated the action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141, the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The amended complaint asserted that the state defendants' conduct violated the Fourteenth Amendment, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 794, and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1401.

The case, assigned to District Judge Gregory K. Frizzell, prompted motion and discovery practice, resulting in unpublished orders by Magistrate Judge Frank H. McCarthy. These orders addressed protective orders for confidential resident information; scheduling on-site inspections at Rader by plaintiff's counsel and expert consultants; cost allocation for security escorts during visits (United States responsible); and recording requirements for interviews conducted during visits.

A settlement was reached, and on September 9, 2008, the court (Judge Frizzell) entered an order incorporating the consent decree. The decree resolved claims regarding protection from harm, suicide and self-harm prevention, mental health care, and special education for juvenile residents. The consent decree was set to expire three years from its signing date.

In September 2011, shortly before the consent decree's expiration, the U.S. filed an emergency motion to modify the decree. The U.S. asserted that following Rader's 2011 closure, incidents occurred at two "replacement" facilities, and defendants denied full investigative access. The U.S. sought to modify the consent decree to extend its applicability to these facilities, enabling court-supported investigations. Defendants objected, arguing Rader was the sole facility under the order and the facilities were not "replacements" as defined by the decree. The court concurred, finding the pre-existing juvenile centers were not replacements under the consent decree's terms. Subsequently, defendants moved to dismiss the case, citing the decree's expiration. The court granted the motion on November 18, 2011, dismissing the case with prejudice.

This case is now closed.

On December 15, 2006, the United States filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the state of Oklahoma and officials operating the L.E. Rader Center ("Rader") juvenile detention facility. The complaint, amended on May 4, 2007, alleged defendants (1) denied Rader's residents rights to protection from harm by staff, other residents, and improper psychotropic drug administration; (2) provided inadequate mental health care, particularly regarding screening, assessment, treatment, and psychiatric and psychological services; and (3) failed to provide required special education services to qualifying residents. The federal government initiated the action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141, the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The amended complaint asserted the state defendants' conduct violated the Fourteenth Amendment, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 794, and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1401.

A settlement was reached, and on September 9, 2008, the court (Judge Frizzell) entered an order incorporating the consent decree. The decree resolved claims regarding protection from harm, suicide and self-harm prevention, mental health care, and special education for juvenile residents. The consent decree was set to expire three years from its signing date.

In September 2011, shortly before the consent decree's expiration, the U.S. filed an emergency motion to modify the decree. The U.S. asserted that following Rader's 2011 closure, incidents occurred at two "replacement" facilities, and defendants denied full investigative access. The U.S. sought to modify the consent decree to extend its applicability to these facilities, enabling court-supported investigations. Defendants objected, arguing Rader was the sole facility under the order and the facilities were not "replacements" as defined by the decree. The court concurred, finding the pre-existing juvenile centers were not replacements under the consent decree's terms. Subsequently, defendants moved to dismiss the case, citing the decree's expiration. The court granted the motion on November 18, 2011, dismissing the case with prejudice.

This case is now closed.

1.transformed_text:
On December 15, 2006, the United States sued the state of Oklahoma and its officials who ran the L.E. Rader Center (a juvenile detention facility). The lawsuit, updated on May 4, 2007, asked the court to declare certain actions illegal and to order the state to change them. The U.S. claimed that the state officials (1) failed to protect Rader residents from harm by staff, other residents, and from wrong use of psychiatric medications; (2) provided poor mental health care, including issues with initial checks, evaluations, treatment, planning for release, and psychiatric services; and (3) did not provide required special education services to residents who qualified. Lawyers from the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division brought this case under a federal law that addresses patterns of civil rights violations. The lawsuit also stated that the state's actions violated the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, along with the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, which are federal laws protecting people with disabilities.

District Judge Gregory K. Frizzell oversaw the case. During this time, the parties filed various legal requests and exchanged information, leading to several orders from Magistrate Judge Frank H. McCarthy in June 2007. These orders dealt with things like keeping information about residents private, arranging site visits to Rader by the U.S. government's lawyers and their experts, deciding that the U.S. would pay for security during these visits, and requiring that interviews conducted during the visits be recorded.

In June 2008, the parties reached a settlement. On September 9, 2008, Judge Frizzell signed an order that officially put the settlement into effect as a "consent decree." This agreement outlined steps to protect young residents from harm, prevent suicide and self-harm, improve mental health care, and ensure special education services. The consent decree was set to end three years after it was signed.

In September 2011, just over a week before the consent decree was to expire, the U.S. filed an urgent request to change the agreement. The U.S. claimed that Rader had closed in 2011, and since then, several problems had occurred at two other facilities that they considered "replacements." The U.S. said the state had not allowed them full access to investigate these problems. Therefore, the U.S. wanted the consent decree to cover these new facilities so the court could help investigate the incidents. The state officials disagreed, arguing that the order only applied to Rader and that these two other facilities were not "replacements" as the consent decree defined them. The court sided with the state, ruling that the existing juvenile centers were not covered by the consent decree. The state then asked the court to close the case, pointing out that the consent decree had expired. The court agreed and dismissed the case permanently on November 18, 2011.

This case is now closed.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine a situation where the U.S. government (like a big brother looking out for everyone) sued the state of Oklahoma in 2006. They sued the people in charge of a place called the L.E. Rader Center, which was a special facility for young people who had gotten into trouble. This lawsuit, updated a few months later, basically asked the court to say, "Hey, what Oklahoma is doing here is wrong," and then to make them fix it.

The U.S. government argued that the state officials weren't keeping the young people at Rader safe. This included not protecting them from harm by the staff, from other kids, and from being given the wrong powerful medications for their minds. They also said the mental health care was really bad. Things like not properly checking kids when they arrived, not figuring out what help they needed, not treating them well, and not planning for their lives after leaving Rader. And that kids with special learning needs weren't getting the special education they were legally supposed to receive. Lawyers from the Department of Justice, which is like the government's legal team, brought this case. They used a federal law designed to stop ongoing patterns of civil rights violations – basically, when someone's basic rights are repeatedly ignored. The lawsuit also said the state broke several important laws: the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution (which is all about making sure everyone is treated fairly and has proper legal steps taken), and two other federal laws, the Rehabilitation Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Act, which are designed to protect people with disabilities.

Judge Gregory K. Frizzell was the judge in charge of this case. While the case was going on, both sides (the U.S. government and Oklahoma officials) made different requests to the court and shared information. This led to a few official orders from another judge, Magistrate Judge Frank H. McCarthy, in June 2007. These orders were about things like: keeping private details about the young people at Rader secret; letting the U.S. government's lawyers and their experts visit Rader to check things out; deciding that the U.S. would pay for security guards during these visits; and making sure that any interviews done during the visits were recorded.

About a year later, in June 2008, both sides worked out an agreement, sort of like a compromise. On September 9, 2008, Judge Frizzell officially approved this agreement, making it a "consent decree." Think of a consent decree as a special court order that makes an agreement between two sides legally binding and enforceable. It's like the judge stamping it "official" and saying, "You *have* to follow this." This agreement laid out clear steps to keep the young people at Rader safe, prevent them from hurting themselves, improve their mental health care, and make sure they got the special education they needed. This special agreement was set to last for three years.

Fast forward to September 2011, just a little over a week before that three-year agreement was supposed to end, the U.S. government made an urgent request to change it. The U.S. said that Rader had actually closed down in 2011. And since then, they claimed there were new problems at two *other* facilities that they saw as basically replacing Rader. The U.S. argued that the state wasn't letting them fully investigate these new issues. So, the U.S. wanted the court's original agreement to now apply to these new places, so the court could help them investigate what was going on. But the state officials pushed back. They said, "No way, that agreement was *only* for Rader. These other two places aren't 'replacements' according to what we agreed to." The court agreed with the state, deciding that the agreement didn't cover these other facilities. Then, the state asked the court to simply close the whole case, since the three-year agreement had now officially ended. The court agreed and officially closed the case for good on November 18, 2011.

So, this particular legal battle is now over.

1.transformed_text:
In December 2006, the United States initiated a legal action against the State of Oklahoma and officials responsible for the L.E. Rader Center, a juvenile detention facility. The federal government, acting through its Civil Rights Division, brought this case because it believed the state was systematically failing to protect the fundamental rights of the juveniles housed there. The amended complaint detailed allegations of inadequate protection from harm by staff and other residents, improper administration of psychotropic drugs, deficient mental health care, and a failure to provide required special education services. This intervention was a strategic move to compel the state to rectify these alleged abuses, asserting violations of the Fourteenth Amendment and federal disability laws.

Once the lawsuit was filed, both sides engaged in the crucial process of information gathering and setting the stage for the legal proceedings. Orders from the Magistrate Judge during this phase were designed to ensure the integrity of the investigation, such as protecting confidential resident information, facilitating on-site inspections by federal counsel and experts, and establishing the practical rules for collecting evidence, including who would bear the costs and whether interviews needed recording. This period was essential for preparing the groundwork, whether for a potential trial or, as it transpired, a negotiated resolution.

By June 2008, the parties strategically opted for a settlement rather than a protracted trial. The court formally adopted this agreement as a consent decree, which outlined specific reforms the state committed to implementing at Rader. This pragmatic solution allowed the state to avoid an adverse judicial finding while agreeing to the changes the federal government sought to ensure the safety and well-being of the juveniles, establishing a court-monitored framework for compliance set to expire in three years.

However, as the consent decree neared its expiration in September 2011, a new challenge emerged. The U.S. filed an emergency motion, seeking to modify the decree because Rader had closed and incidents were reported at two "replacement" facilities. This was a strategic attempt by the federal government to maintain judicial oversight and ensure the reforms continued to protect juveniles, even if they were moved. The defendants, however, strategically objected, arguing that the decree's terms were specific to Rader and did not encompass these other facilities. The court sided with the defendants, finding the pre-existing centers were not "replacements" under the decree's terms. With the original mandate's scope limited and its expiration imminent, the defendants then successfully moved to dismiss the entire case in November 2011, effectively ending the federal government's direct oversight.

No. 206, the New York State Police was directed to supply the Court with both redacted and unredacted documents responsive to a subpoena issued by Defendant Smith on December 10, 2020 fo r an in camera review. After review, the Court concludes that only the following additional unredacted documents should be prov ided to defense counsel pursuant to the subpoena:  1. The New York State Police Level I Investigative Form, dated September 9, 2012 (5 pages). 2.  The To/From Memorandum dated November 1, 2011 (2pages).  3. The Interview Transcript of Senior Investig ator Christopher O'Brien dated December 8, 2011 (12 pages).  4.  The Typed Statement of Alexander McDonald dated February 27, 2012 (8 pages, unsigned). The Court concludes that there is information contained in these documents that is proportion ally relevant to the needs of this case, and directly relates to issues that were the subject of a lengthy deposition of former Investigator O'Brien.  In connection with the in camera submission, counsel for the New York State Police requested p ermission to submit further objections in the event that the Court were to order the release of additional documents.  Since the Court is proposing to do so, the Court will grant the New York State Police counsel's office until June 11, 2021 to submit any additional arguments.IT IS SO ORDERED.. original_case_data.name: McDonough v. Smith, III
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: The former Rensselaer County Democratic Elections Commissioner who alleged that fabricated evidence was used to pursue criminal charges against him.
original_case_data.summary:
On December 18, 2015, almost three years after the former Rensselaer County Democratic Elections Commissioner was acquitted in state court of forging absentee ballots in a local primary election, he filed this suit against the County of Rensselaer and multiple individuals who he alleged were involved in his prosecution, including the Special District Attorney for the County. The plaintiff filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. Specifically, the plaintiff alleged malicious prosecution without probable cause and argued that the Special District Attorney fabricated evidence to pursue criminal charges against him. The plaintiff sought compensatory and punitive damages, medical expenses and costs, and attorneys’ fees. U.S. District Judge Mae A. D’Agostino presided over this case.

On September 30, 2016, the district court ruled on multiple motions to dismiss, dismissing five defendants from the action, and granting in part and denying in part another defendant’s motion to dismiss. While the district court found that the plaintiff had adequately pleaded facts to support a malicious prosecution claim against one of the defendants, the court dismissed the plaintiff’s fabrication of evidence claims against all the defendants on statute of limitations grounds. Three months later, the district court ruled on three more motions to dismiss. First, the court dismissed the County as a defendant, reasoning that a municipality cannot be held liable solely based on the actions of city employees. The court also dismissed the Special District Attorney as a defendant, finding that he was entitled to absolute prosecutorial immunity. Lastly, the court granted in part and denied in part the motion to dismiss by a defendant who was assigned to assist the Special District Attorney in the investigation of the plaintiff. The court found that the defendant was entitled to absolute immunity for his grand jury and trial testimony. However, it also found that plaintiff had sufficiently alleged that the defendant acted in conjunction with the Special District Attorney to maliciously prosecute the plaintiff by ignoring or failing to obtain evidence that would have incriminated other defendants in order to continue prosecuting the plaintiff. 2016 WL 7496128.

On January 27, 2017, the plaintiff appealed both the district court’s dismissal of his fabrication of evidence claim and the court’s finding that the Special District Attorney was entitled to absolute immunity for the malicious prosecution claim. On August 3, 2018, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the district court’s holding that the Special District Attorney was entitled to absolute immunity for the malicious prosecution claim given that the malicious prosecution claim related to actions he took while acting in a prosecutorial capacity. The Second Circuit also held that the fabricated-evidence claim was properly dismissed as untimely given that the limitations period began to run when the plaintiff was arrested and stood trial, not when the plaintiff was acquitted. 898 F.3d 259. 

The plaintiff subsequently appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted certiorari to resolve the question of when the statute of limitations for a fabricated-evidence claim begins to run. The district court stayed discovery and further proceedings pending the Supreme Court’s decision. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court held that the limitations period began to run when the criminal proceedings against the plaintiff terminated in his favor, and thus reversed and remanded the case. 588 U.S. 109.

The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on June 8, 2020, against five defendants, alleging that they fabricated evidence against him and maliciously prosecuted him without probable cause, and that both of those actions violated the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. However, on October 30, 2020, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the amended complaint against four defendants, leaving the Special District Attorney as the only remaining defendant.

The Special District Attorney subsequently moved to dismiss and, in the alternative, moved for summary judgment. On August 11, 2022, the district court granted the Special District Attorney’s motion for summary judgment, dismissed the plaintiff’s amended complaint with prejudice, and ordered judgment in favor of the defendant, finding that nothing in the record suggested that the defendant fabricated evidence or coerced individuals into perjuring themselves. 2022 WL 3279348. 

This case is now closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: multiple defendants, including the Special District Attorney for the County of Rensselaer. Almost three years after the plaintiff was acquitted in state court of forging absentee ballots in a local primary election, he filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging malicious prosecution without probable cause and that the Special District Attorney fabricated evidence to pursue criminal charges against him. The plaintiff sought compensatory and punitive damages, medical expenses and costs, and attorneys’ fees. The district court and the Second Circuit held that the Special District Attorney was entitled to absolute immunity as to the malicious prosecution claim and that the fabricated-evidence claim was untimely because the statute of limitations began to run when the commissioner was arrested and stood trial. 898 F.3d 259. The Supreme Court granted certiorari on the statute of limitations question and reversed, finding that the statute of limitations began to run when the criminal proceedings against the commissioner were terminated in his favor. 588 U.S. 109. On August 11, 2022,  the district court granted the Special District Attorney’s motion for summary judgment, dismissed the plaintiff’s amended complaint with prejudice, and ordered judgment in favor of the defendant, finding that nothing in the record suggested that the defendant fabricated evidence or coerced individuals into perjuring themselves. 2022 WL 3279348. This case is now closed.
original_case_data.summary_tiny: New to the Clearinghouse: In case alleging malicious prosecution of election commissioner, SCOTUS held in 2019 that statute of limitations on a fabricated evidence claim began to run when criminal proceedings against plaintiff terminated in his favor.

Lastly, the court granted in part and denied in part the motion to dismiss by a defendant assigned to assist the Special District Attorney in the investigation of the plaintiff. The court found this defendant was entitled to absolute immunity for his grand jury and trial testimony. However, it also found that plaintiff had sufficiently alleged that the defendant acted in conjunction with the Special District Attorney to maliciously prosecute the plaintiff by ignoring or failing to obtain evidence that would have incriminated other defendants to continue prosecuting the plaintiff.

On August 3, 2018, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the district court’s finding of absolute prosecutorial immunity for the Special District Attorney, given the malicious prosecution claim related to actions taken in a prosecutorial capacity. The Second Circuit also held that the fabricated-evidence claim was properly dismissed as untimely given that the limitations period began to run when the plaintiff was arrested and stood trial, not when the plaintiff was acquitted.

The plaintiff subsequently appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted certiorari to resolve the question of when the statute of limitations for a fabricated-evidence claim begins to run. The district court stayed discovery and further proceedings pending the Supreme Court’s decision. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court held that the limitations period began to run when the criminal proceedings against the plaintiff terminated in his favor, and thus reversed and remanded the case.

Following remand, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint against five defendants, alleging that they fabricated evidence against him and maliciously prosecuted him without probable cause, and that these actions violated his Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. However, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the amended complaint against four defendants, leaving the Special District Attorney as the only remaining defendant.

The Special District Attorney subsequently moved to dismiss or, in the alternative, for summary judgment. On August 11, 2022, the district court granted the Special District Attorney’s motion for summary judgment, dismissed the plaintiff’s amended complaint with prejudice, and ordered judgment in favor of the defendant, finding that nothing in the record suggested that the defendant fabricated evidence or coerced individuals into perjuring themselves.

This case is now closed.

On December 18, 2015, the former Rensselaer County Democratic Elections Commissioner, previously acquitted in state court of forging absentee ballots, initiated a civil action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. The plaintiff asserted violations of his Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights against the County of Rensselaer and multiple individuals involved in his prosecution, including the Special District Attorney. Core allegations included malicious prosecution without probable cause and the Special District Attorney’s fabrication of evidence. The plaintiff sought compensatory and punitive damages, medical expenses, and attorneys’ fees. U.S. District Judge Mae A. D’Agostino presided.

The district court subsequently adjudicated multiple motions to dismiss. The court dismissed five defendants from the action entirely. The plaintiff’s fabrication of evidence claims against all defendants were dismissed on statute of limitations grounds. The County was dismissed, with the court reasoning that municipal liability could not be based solely on employee actions. The Special District Attorney was dismissed as a defendant, the court determining he was entitled to absolute prosecutorial immunity. A motion by a defendant assigned to assist the Special District Attorney was granted in part and denied in part; this defendant received absolute immunity for grand jury and trial testimony, but the court found sufficient allegations that he acted in conjunction with the Special District Attorney to maliciously prosecute the plaintiff by disregarding exculpatory evidence.

The plaintiff appealed the district court’s dismissal of his fabrication of evidence claim and the Special District Attorney's absolute immunity for the malicious prosecution claim. On August 3, 2018, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the district court’s finding of absolute prosecutorial immunity for the Special District Attorney, concluding the malicious prosecution claim related to actions taken in a prosecutorial capacity. The Second Circuit also affirmed the dismissal of the fabricated-evidence claim as untimely, holding that the limitations period commenced upon the plaintiff’s arrest and trial, not his acquittal.

Subsequently, the plaintiff petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted certiorari to resolve the commencement of the statute of limitations for a fabricated-evidence claim. During this period, the district court stayed discovery and further proceedings. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court ruled that the limitations period began when the criminal proceedings against the plaintiff terminated in his favor, thus reversing and remanding the case.

Following remand, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint against five defendants, reasserting claims of fabricated evidence and malicious prosecution without probable cause, in violation of his Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. The plaintiff later voluntarily dismissed the amended complaint against four defendants, leaving the Special District Attorney as the sole remaining defendant.

1.transformed_text:
On December 18, 2015, almost three years after a former Rensselaer County Democratic Elections Commissioner was found not guilty in state court of faking absentee ballots in a local primary election, he sued Rensselaer County and several people he claimed were involved in his prosecution, including the County's Special District Attorney. He filed this lawsuit in federal court (U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York) under a law called 42 U.S.C. § 1983. He claimed his constitutional rights under the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments were violated. Specifically, he claimed he was maliciously prosecuted (meaning he was wrongly prosecuted without good reason) and that the Special District Attorney made up evidence to bring criminal charges against him. He asked for money to cover his losses (compensatory damages), extra money to punish the defendants (punitive damages), medical expenses, and legal fees. U.S. District Judge Mae A. D’Agostino oversaw the case.

On September 30, 2016, the district court decided on several motions to dismiss the case. The court dismissed five defendants entirely and partly granted, partly denied another defendant’s request to dismiss. The court found the plaintiff had presented enough facts to support his malicious prosecution claim against one defendant. However, it dismissed his claims that evidence was fabricated against all defendants because the lawsuit was filed too late (due to the "statute of limitations"). Three months later, the district court made decisions on three more requests to dismiss. First, the court dismissed the County as a defendant, explaining that a local government cannot be held responsible just because its employees acted wrongly. The court also dismissed the Special District Attorney, ruling that he had "absolute prosecutorial immunity," meaning he was protected from lawsuits for actions taken as a prosecutor. Finally, the court partly granted and partly denied the motion to dismiss from a defendant who helped the Special District Attorney investigate the plaintiff. The court found this defendant was also protected by "absolute immunity" for what he said when testifying to the grand jury and at trial. However, the court also found that the plaintiff had sufficiently claimed that this defendant worked with the Special District Attorney to wrongly prosecute him. This was done by ignoring or failing to get evidence that would have shown other defendants were guilty, so they could keep prosecuting the plaintiff instead. 2016 WL 7496128.

On January 27, 2017, the plaintiff appealed two of the district court's decisions: the dismissal of his claim that evidence was fabricated, and the ruling that the Special District Attorney had "absolute immunity" for the malicious prosecution claim. On August 3, 2018, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit agreed with the district court. They upheld the decision that the Special District Attorney had "absolute immunity" for the malicious prosecution claim because his actions were part of his job as a prosecutor. The Second Circuit also ruled that the fabricated-evidence claim was correctly dismissed as being filed too late. They said the time limit for filing the claim started when the plaintiff was arrested and went to trial, not when he was found not guilty. 898 F.3d 259.

The plaintiff then appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case (granted "certiorari") to decide when the time limit for filing a fabricated-evidence claim actually begins. The district court paused the collection of evidence ("discovery") and other legal steps until the Supreme Court made its decision. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court ruled that the time limit started when the criminal case against the plaintiff ended in his favor. Because of this, they overturned the lower court's decision and sent the case back for further action ("reversed and remanded"). 588 U.S. 109.

The plaintiff filed an updated complaint on June 8, 2020, against five defendants. He claimed they fabricated evidence and maliciously prosecuted him without good reason, and that both actions violated his Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. However, on October 30, 2020, the plaintiff chose to drop the case against four of the defendants, leaving only the Special District Attorney as the sole defendant.

The Special District Attorney then asked the court to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to rule in his favor without a trial ("summary judgment"). On August 11, 2022, the district court granted the Special District Attorney's request for summary judgment. This meant the plaintiff's updated complaint was dismissed permanently ("with prejudice"), and the court ruled in favor of the defendant. The court found no evidence in the case file to suggest the defendant fabricated evidence or forced people to lie under oath ("perjure themselves"). 2022 WL 3279348.

This case is now closed.
