On December 18, 2015, a former Rensselaer County elections official filed a lawsuit. This was nearly three years after he was cleared of charges in state court for faking votes in a local election. He sued Rensselaer County and several people he said were involved in his case, including the County's Special District Attorney. He filed his case in a federal court in New York. He sued under a federal civil rights law. He claimed his basic rights under the U.S. Constitution were violated. He said he was wrongly prosecuted without good reason, a claim known as "malicious prosecution." He also claimed the Special District Attorney created false evidence to charge him with a crime. He asked for money to cover his losses and extra money to punish those he sued. He also sought medical expenses and legal fees. U.S. District Judge Mae A. D’Agostino handled the case.

On September 30, 2016, the district court ruled on several requests to throw out the case. The court removed five people he sued from the case. It also partially approved and partially rejected another person's request to be dismissed. The court found the plaintiff had provided enough information to support his claim of malicious prosecution against one person. However, it dismissed his claims that evidence was created falsely against all defendants. This was because the lawsuit was filed too late, past a legal deadline known as the "statute of limitations." Three months later, the court made decisions on three more requests to dismiss. First, the court dismissed the County from the lawsuit. It explained that a local government isn't automatically responsible just because its employees acted wrongly. The court also dismissed the Special District Attorney. It ruled he had "absolute prosecutorial immunity," which means he was fully protected from lawsuits for actions he took as a prosecutor. Finally, the court partially approved and partially rejected a request to dismiss from someone who helped the Special District Attorney investigate the plaintiff. The court found this person also had "absolute immunity," meaning full legal protection, for what he said when testifying to the grand jury and at trial. However, the court also found the plaintiff had provided enough information to claim this person worked with the Special District Attorney to wrongly prosecute him. This was done by ignoring or failing to get evidence that would have shown other defendants were guilty. Their goal was to keep prosecuting the plaintiff instead.

On January 27, 2017, the plaintiff challenged two of the district court's decisions. He appealed the dismissal of his claim that evidence was created falsely. He also appealed the ruling that the Special District Attorney had "absolute immunity" for the malicious prosecution claim. On August 3, 2018, a higher court, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, agreed with the district court. They confirmed the decision that the Special District Attorney had "absolute immunity" for the malicious prosecution claim. This was because his actions were part of his job as a prosecutor. The Second Circuit also ruled that the claim about false evidence was correctly dismissed because it was filed too late. They said the time limit for filing the claim began when the plaintiff was arrested and went to trial, not when he was found not guilty.

The plaintiff then appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case, a process called "granting certiorari." They wanted to decide when the time limit for filing a false evidence claim actually begins. The district court paused the collection of evidence, known as "discovery," and other legal steps. This pause lasted until the Supreme Court made its decision. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court ruled that the time limit started when the criminal case against the plaintiff ended in his favor. Because of this, they overturned the lower court's decision. They sent the case back for further action, a process called "reversed and remanded."

On June 8, 2020, the plaintiff filed an updated complaint against five people. He claimed they created false evidence and wrongly prosecuted him without good reason. He said both actions violated his basic constitutional rights. However, on October 30, 2020, the plaintiff chose to drop the case against four of them. This left only the Special District Attorney as the single remaining defendant.

The Special District Attorney then asked the court to dismiss the case. Alternatively, he asked for a ruling in his favor without a trial, a process called "summary judgment." On August 11, 2022, the district court approved the Special District Attorney's request for summary judgment. This meant the plaintiff's updated complaint was dismissed permanently, a ruling "with prejudice." The court ruled in favor of the defendant. The court found no evidence in the case file. It saw nothing to suggest the defendant created false evidence or forced people to lie under oath.

This case is now closed.

However, the court also found that the former official had given enough information to claim this person worked with the special prosecutor to wrongly put him on trial. He said they did this by ignoring or not getting evidence that would have shown other people were guilty, because their main goal was to keep prosecuting him.

The plaintiff subsequently appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted certiorari to resolve the question of when the statute of limitations for a fabricated-evidence claim begins to run. The district court stayed discovery and further proceedings pending the Supreme Court’s decision. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court held that the limitations period began to run when the criminal proceedings against the plaintiff terminated in his favor, and thus reversed and remanded the case. 588 U.S. 109.

The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on June 8, 2020, against five defendants, alleging that they fabricated evidence against him and maliciously prosecuted him without probable cause, and that both of those actions violated the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. However, on October 30, 2020, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the amended complaint against four defendants, leaving the Special District Attorney as the only remaining defendant.

The Special District Attorney subsequently moved to dismiss and, in the alternative, moved for summary judgment. On August 11, 2022, the district court granted the Special District Attorney’s motion for summary judgment, dismissed the plaintiff’s amended complaint with prejudice, and ordered judgment in favor of the defendant, finding that nothing in the record suggested that the defendant fabricated evidence or coerced individuals into perjuring themselves. 2022 WL 3279348. 

This case is now closed.

Years after his acquittal in a state court trial for forging absentee ballots, the former Rensselaer County Democratic Elections Commissioner initiated a federal lawsuit on December 18, 2015. He sought to hold accountable the County of Rensselaer and several individuals, including the Special District Attorney, whom he believed had orchestrated his wrongful prosecution. His core contention was that he had been maliciously prosecuted without probable cause, and critically, that the Special District Attorney had fabricated evidence to secure his criminal charges. Through this action, he aimed to recover damages for the harm he had suffered.

The defendants swiftly responded to the plaintiff's allegations by filing motions to dismiss, a strategic move to end the lawsuit early without the need for a full trial. They argued that the plaintiff's claims lacked legal merit or were procedurally flawed. On September 30, 2016, the district court largely sided with the defendants, removing five individuals from the suit and dismissing the plaintiff's fabrication of evidence claims against all parties, citing that too much time had passed since the alleged wrongdoing. Later, the court further narrowed the case, dismissing the County itself, on the principle that a government entity isn't automatically responsible for its employees' actions. Crucially, the Special District Attorney was also dismissed, as the court determined he was shielded by absolute prosecutorial immunity for his actions. However, the court allowed a claim for malicious prosecution to proceed against one defendant, an assistant to the Special District Attorney, acknowledging the plaintiff's compelling argument that this individual had acted in concert to maliciously prosecute him by overlooking evidence that might have implicated others.

Unsatisfied with these dismissals, the plaintiff pursued an appeal, seeking to revive his fabrication of evidence claim and challenge the Special District Attorney's immunity. He believed these rulings unjustly curtailed his pursuit of justice. However, on August 3, 2018, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit largely affirmed the lower court's decisions. The appellate court agreed that the Special District Attorney was immune for his prosecutorial actions and, significantly, reaffirmed that the time limit for the fabricated-evidence claim began when the plaintiff was arrested and tried, not when he was ultimately acquitted, thus upholding its dismissal as untimely.

Undeterred, the plaintiff brought his case to the U.S. Supreme Court, which took the unusual step of agreeing to hear it. The Court recognized a crucial legal ambiguity: precisely when the clock should start ticking for a fabricated-evidence claim's statute of limitations. This was a pivotal question for the plaintiff, as its resolution would determine if his claim could proceed. On June 19, 2019, the Supreme Court sided with the plaintiff, ruling that the limitations period began only when the criminal proceedings against him concluded in his favor. This landmark decision breathed new life into his case, reversing the lower court's dismissal and sending the matter back for further proceedings.

With the Supreme Court's ruling in hand, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint on June 8, 2020, renewing his allegations of fabricated evidence and malicious prosecution against five defendants. However, in a strategic move to streamline the case, he voluntarily dismissed four of these defendants on October 30, 2020, choosing to focus his efforts solely on the Special District Attorney.

The Special District Attorney, now the sole defendant, again sought to end the litigation, this time by moving for summary judgment. This motion aimed to demonstrate that there was no genuine dispute of material fact and that he was entitled to judgment as a matter of law, thereby avoiding a trial. On August 11, 2022, the district court agreed, granting summary judgment in his favor. The court found no evidence in the extensive record to support the plaintiff's claims that the Special District Attorney had fabricated evidence or coerced witnesses. This final ruling brought the long-running legal battle to a close.

Thus, the case was finally closed.
